constraints.subject: ANTH
constraints.description: Not including numbers reserved for senior essay work.

senior_requirement.description: All majors must complete a substantial senior essay during the senior year, either written within an advanced seminar or through ANTH 4091, with a yearlong option beginning in ANTH 4071 and completed in ANTH 4091. Seminar essays must be approved by the instructor by the third week and are evaluated by the instructor and a second Yale faculty reader.

Independent Senior Essay.description: An independent essay on a subject of the student’s choice completed in ANTH 4091; topic and adviser approved by the end of the third week, with a prospectus and identification of a second reader.

Yearlong Senior Essay.description: A yearlong project begun in ANTH 4071 (typically fall term) and completed in ANTH 4091; requires prior approval by a faculty adviser who sets ANTH 4071 requirements.

policies.credit_d_fail_note: No more than one course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the requirements of the major.

outside_credit.notes: Up to two courses taken outside Yale may be applied as electives or cognates toward the Anthropology major. Approved study abroad courses may replace one elective; using more than one study abroad credit reduces the number of allowable cognate courses.

other_policies.cognate_courses_dus_approval: With DUS approval, up to three cognate courses from other departments or programs may count toward the major.
other_policies.study_abroad_credit: Approved study abroad courses may replace one elective; using more than one study abroad credit reduces the number of allowable cognate courses.
other_policies.graduate_courses_permission: Most graduate seminars in anthropology are open to qualified undergraduates with permission of the instructor and the director of graduate studies.
other_policies.double_major_senior_essay_limit: A single seminar essay may not be applied toward the senior requirement for two majors.
other_policies.senior_essay_readers: For independent and yearlong essays, the adviser must have a faculty appointment in Anthropology and the second reader must have a Yale faculty appointment.
other_policies.concentrations_note: Optional concentrations (Archaeology; Biological Anthropology; Sociocultural Anthropology; Medical Anthropology and Global Health) have additional requirements and recommendations that fit within the overall major.

provenance.quote: Students are required to present twelve course credits toward their major, including at least one introductory or intermediate (1000-2000 level) course in each of the three subfields of anthropology, at least three advanced courses (3000-4000 level), not including numbers reserved for senior essay work, and a senior essay.
No more than one course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the requirements of the major.
With approval from the director of undergraduate studies (DUS), up to three courses may be selected from other departments as cognates.
Courses taken at another institution or during an approved summer or term-time study abroad program may count toward the major requirements with DUS approval.
All majors are required to complete a substantial paper during their senior year, either in a seminar or in ANTH 4091.
Option 3: A yearlong paper, begun in ANTH 4071 and completed in ANTH 4091.

constraints.subject: African language
constraints.description: Language requirement may be waived by placement testing; if waived, substitute four African Studies courses. Other African languages may be used with DUS permission.
An alternative research methods course may be approved by the DUS if it deepens the focus or provides methodological tools for the senior essay.

Selected in consultation with the DUS in a discipline or interdisciplinary/cross-disciplinary area (e.g., Anthropology, Art History, History, Languages and Literature, Political Science, Sociology; African American Studies; Ethnicity, Race, and Migration; Women’s, Gender, and Sexuality Studies; diaspora or development studies).

senior_requirement.description: Complete a senior essay in AFST 4491 under the guidance of a faculty adviser; with prior DUS approval, a combined senior essay may be submitted for students pursuing a second major. A preliminary statement with topic and adviser is due by the end of the second week of the fall term in the senior year.

Standard.description: One-term senior essay course.

policies.credit_d_fail_note: No more than one course taken for Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the requirements of the major.

outside_credit.notes: Courses taken at another institution or during an approved summer or term-time study abroad program may count toward the major requirements with DUS approval.

other_policies.language_waiver_and_placement: For languages not regularly offered at Yale, an equivalent placement test administered through the Center for Language Study may waive the requirement; if waived, students must substitute four African Studies courses.
other_policies.additional_language_courses: With DUS permission, courses in an additional language (e.g., French or Portuguese) may count toward major requirements.
other_policies.advising: Students planning to major in African Studies should consult the DUS as early as possible.
other_policies.language_study_timing: Students should begin their African language study as early as possible.

provenance.quote: The African Studies program consists of twelve term courses...
one African Studies course in the humanities and one in the social sciences
two years of an African language (Arabic, Kiswahili, Twi, Wolof, Yorùbá, isiZulu, or others with permission of the DUS), unless waived by examination
one research methods course, AFST 5505 or an alternative course... selected in consultation with the DUS
four courses in an area of focus... or in a cross-disciplinary area such as diaspora studies or development studies
AFST 4491, the senior essay
If the requirement is waived, students must substitute other African Studies courses for the four required language courses.
With permission of the DUS, students may count courses in an additional language, such as French or Portuguese, toward the major requirements.
Credit/D/Fail... No more than one course taken for Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the requirements of the major.
Outside credit... may count toward the major requirements with DUS approval.
Students are required to complete a senior essay in AFST 4491... A preliminary statement... must be submitted... in the senior year.

policies.credit_d_fail_note: No course taken Credit/D/Fail may be counted toward the program in Aerospace Studies.

other_policies.courses_open_to_all_students: Enrollment in Aerospace Studies courses is open to any Yale student.
other_policies.graduation_credit: Most Aerospace Studies courses count only for enrollment credit; USAF 2014, USAF 4011, and USAF 4014 count toward graduation credit.
other_policies.leadership_lab: Cadets must participate in a mandatory two-hour leadership laboratory each week.
other_policies.afrotc_course_sequence: AFROTC cadets typically take one USAF course per semester and complete eight total.

provenance.quote: Students in the AFROTC program must successfully complete eight USAF courses total, typically taking one course per semester.
AFROTC cadets typically take one USAF course per semester and complete eight total.
The Department of Aerospace Studies offers these courses: USAF 1001, 1002, 2001, 2002, 3001, 3002, 4001, 4002, 4011, and 4014.
When the Department of History offers HIST 1221...cadets may use it to fulfill the one term of the 2000-level AFROTC requirement (USAF 2002).
Most Aerospace Studies courses count for enrollment credit only... USAF 2014, USAF 4011, and USAF 4014 do count toward graduation credit.
Enrollment in Aerospace Studies courses is not limited to cadets; courses are open to any Yale student.
Cadets become involved in the management of their own cadet wing through a mandatory two-hour leadership laboratory each week.
No course taken Credit/D/Fail may be counted toward the program in Aerospace Studies.

distributions.category: Humanities course in African American literature
Social science course relevant to African American Studies

constraints.description: Area of focus must be approved by DUS.

senior_requirement.description: Senior majors complete AFAM 4380 (colloquium) to develop a prospectus, bibliography, and first twenty pages, then complete a senior essay in AFAM 4391 under faculty guidance.

Standard.description: Take AFAM 4380 followed by AFAM 4391 to research and write the senior essay.

policies.credit_d_fail_note: No more than one course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the requirements of the major.

outside_credit.notes: Courses taken at another institution or during approved study abroad may count toward the major with DUS approval. A limited number of courses during sophomore or junior semesters abroad can be counted toward the major with DUS approval.

other_policies.focus_area_exclusions: None of the seven core courses may be counted among the required electives in the area of focus.
other_policies.junior_seminar_timing: AFAM 4310 must be taken in the junior year.
other_policies.double_major_option: May be taken as one of two majors; consult the DUS in African American Studies and the other department; a joint thesis may be possible.
other_policies.dus_advising: Students should consult the DUS early; areas of focus and schedules must be approved by the DUS.
other_policies.study_abroad: A limited number of courses taken during sophomore or junior semesters abroad can be counted toward the major with DUS approval.

provenance.quote: The major in African American Studies requires twelve term courses, including seven core courses and five electives in a focus area.

The seven core courses include the African American history sequence AFAM 1160 and AFAM 1162 ... one humanities course in African American literature; one course in the social sciences ... the junior seminar (AFAM 4310); the senior colloquium (AFAM 4380) and senior essay (AFAM 4391).
None of the seven core courses may be counted among the required electives in the area of focus.
In their junior year students must take the junior seminar, AFAM 4310.
Senior majors participate in a colloquium in AFAM 4380 ... write the first twenty pages of the senior essay. After completing the colloquium ... a senior essay in AFAM 4391.
No more than one course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the requirements of the major.
Courses taken at another institution or during an approved summer or term-time study abroad program may count toward the major requirements with DUS approval.
A limited number of courses taken during sophomore or junior semesters abroad can be counted toward the major with DUS approval.
Areas of focus and schedules for majors must be approved by the DUS.
African American Studies can be taken either as a stand-alone major or as one of two majors.

distributions.category: Gateway course with Early Americas attribute
Junior seminar in area of concentration

senior_requirement.description: Complete the senior requirement in one of three ways: (1) a senior seminar within the area of concentration (AMST 4000–4999) with a 20–25 page final paper and submission of a senior seminar registration form; (2) a one-term senior project or essay (AMST 4491) producing a 30-page essay or equivalent, with prospectus approved by a faculty adviser; or (3) the intensive major (AMST 4493 and 4494) over two terms leading to a 60-page project or equivalent, including participation in a yearlong proseminar; one term of the two-term project may count toward the area of concentration.

Senior Project.description: One-term senior project or essay; 30-page essay or equivalent in another medium; prospectus signed by the faculty adviser submitted to the DUS and undergraduate registrar.

Intensive Major.description: Two-term intensive major leading to a substantial senior project (approximately 60 pages or equivalent); includes a yearlong proseminar on theory and methods; one term may count as a course in the area of concentration.

policies.credit_d_fail_note: No more than two courses taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the requirements of the major.

outside_credit.notes: Courses taken at another institution or during approved summer or term-time study abroad may count toward the major with DUS approval.

other_policies.gateway_completion_timeline: Gateway courses should be completed by the end of the sophomore year, but no later than the end of the junior year.
other_policies.gateway_substitution: With DUS permission, one First-Year Seminar may substitute for one gateway course.
other_policies.gateway_content_requirements: The four gateway courses must include two in cultural history/cultural studies, one broad survey in American literature, and one preparatory course for the student's area of concentration; one of the four must be designated as an Early Americas course.
other_policies.junior_seminars_timing: Two junior seminars must be taken during the junior year; sophomores contemplating a junior term abroad are urged to take one junior seminar in the spring of the sophomore year.
other_policies.junior_seminar_in_concentration: At least one junior seminar must fall within the student's area of concentration.
other_policies.area_of_concentration_selection: Each major selects an area of concentration, normally in the fall of the junior year; students may petition the DUS to develop an independent concentration.
other_policies.concentration_courses_letter_grade: Five concentration courses from diverse disciplines must be taken for a letter grade.
other_policies.concentration_non_us_topic: Among the concentration courses, one must incorporate a comparable topic from a non-U.S. perspective.
other_policies.amst_electives_requirement: Two electives must be chosen from American Studies course offerings.
other_policies.senior_seminar_admin: Senior seminar option requires submission of a seminar registration form signed by the instructor to the DUS and undergraduate registrar.
other_policies.senior_project_admin: AMST 4491 requires submission of a prospectus signed by the faculty adviser to the DUS and undergraduate registrar.
other_policies.intensive_major_admin: AMST 4493 and 4494 require submission of a prospectus signed by the faculty adviser to the DUS and undergraduate registrar and participation in a yearlong proseminar.
other_policies.intensive_major_concentration_count: One term of AMST 4493/4494 may count as a course in the area of concentration.
other_policies.combined_ba_ma: Exceptionally able students may pursue simultaneous award of the B.A. and M.A.; consult the DUS prior to the sixth term for specific requirements.

provenance.quote: Number of courses: 14 term courses (incl senior req).

Completion of at least four gateway courses (AMST 1000–2999) by end of sophomore year, no later than end of junior year; two in cultural history/cultural studies, one broad survey in American literature, one preparatory course; one must be listed as an Early Americas course.
Students must take two junior seminars (AMST 3000–3999) during their junior year; at least one must fall within the student's area of concentration.
An additional five concentration courses from diverse disciplines must be taken for a letter grade, one of which must incorporate a comparable topic from a non-U.S. perspective.
Two electives chosen from the American Studies course offerings are also required.
Senior requirement: senior seminar (AMST 4000–4999) with 20–25 page paper; one-term senior project or essay (AMST 4491); or intensive major (AMST 4493 and 4494) with 60-page project.
Credit/D/Fail: No more than two courses taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the requirements of the major.
Outside credit: Courses taken at another institution or during approved study abroad may count toward the major with DUS approval.
Substitution permitted: 1 first-year sem for 1 gateway course; others with DUS permission.

prerequisites.must_complete_by: before or during the sophomore year

constraints.description: Courses selected from breadth areas (a)–(m); with DUS approval.
At least two courses at 3000+ level; concentration plan must be approved by DUS.

senior_requirement.description: Senior thesis research project

Standard.description: Complete AMTH 4910 as a senior thesis research project.

policies.credit_d_fail_note: No more than one course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the requirements of the major.

outside_credit.notes: Courses taken at another institution or during approved study abroad may count toward the major requirements.

other_policies.Distinction in the major: Earn A or A− in at least 9/11 (B.A.) or 11/14 (B.S.) non-prerequisite courses; one A/A− must be from AMTH 4900 or AMTH 4910; grades of Cr count as non-A; prerequisite grades and P or W do not count.
other_policies.Second major overlap: A two-course overlap is permitted between Applied Mathematics and a second major; the concentration requirement is flexible to recognize the contribution of the other major.
other_policies.BS additional requirements: In addition to B.A. courses, B.S. requires a vector analysis course (MATH 3020 or MATH 3050; MATH 3100, 3200, 3250, 4470, and 3000+ PDE/analysis replacements allowed; MATH 3500 and 4400 may be considered in consultation with the DUS), one additional course from item 5 breadth areas, and another 3000+ course from breadth or in mathematics/applied mathematics/statistics/quantitative computer science or engineering, or as approved by the DUS. The vector analysis course selected may not be counted under item 5 breadth.
other_policies.BS alternative path: Students may petition to receive a B.S. in Applied Mathematics by fulfilling the B.A. requirements in Applied Mathematics and the B.S. requirements in another program.
other_policies.Breadth substitution (Chemistry): Chemistry courses numbered 410 and above may count as one breadth requirement (either 1 full-term 1 credit or 2 half-credit courses) with DUS permission.
other_policies.Program planning approval: Details of individual programs must be worked out in consultation with the DUS; signed permission required.

provenance.quote: Multivariable calculus and linear algebra are required... may be satisfied by MATH 1200 or ENAS 1510, and MATH 2220 or 2250 or 2260. Computer programming skills are also required... ENAS 1300 or CPSC 1001.
The program requires eleven term courses beyond the prerequisites, including the senior project.
A course in differential equations (ENAS 1940 or MATH 2460).
A course in probability (S&DS 2410 or S&DS 2380).
A course in data analysis (S&DS 3610 or S&DS 2300).
A course in discrete mathematics (AMTH 2440 or CPSC 2020).
Courses in at least three of the following areas* (with DUS approval).
At least three advanced courses in a field of concentration... at least two of which are level 3000+.
B.A.—11 term courses beyond prereqs (incl senior req); B.S.—14 term courses beyond prereqs (incl senior req).
A vector analysis course (MATH 3020 or MATH 3050)... replacements allowed; the course selected may not be counted toward item 5.
No more than one course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the requirements of the major.
Both the B.A. and B.S. degree programs require a senior thesis research project (AMTH 4910).
Details of individual programs must be worked out in consultation with the DUS, whose signed permission is required.
Courses taken at another institution or during approved study abroad may count toward the major requirements with DUS approval.
Chemistry courses numbered 410 and above may count as one breadth requirement with DUS permission.

constraints.description: Three advanced courses in physical or mathematical sciences or engineering in an area of focus.

senior_requirement.description: Independent research project under supervision in Applied Physics, Physics, Engineering, or related departments; taken as APHY 4710 and APHY 4720; may begin in junior year and be completed in senior year.

Standard.description: Senior special projects constituting the independent research requirement.

policies.credit_d_fail_note: No more than one course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the major with permission of the DUS.

outside_credit.notes: Courses taken at another institution or during approved study abroad may count toward the major.

other_policies.letter_grade_requirement: APHY 4710 and APHY 4720 must be taken for a letter grade.
other_policies.advising: Students should consult the DUS early; substitutions of equivalent courses may be permitted with DUS approval.
other_policies.course_substitutions: Substitutions of equivalent courses may be permitted with DUS approval.

provenance.quote: Prerequisites: PHYS 1800, 1810, or PHYS 2000, 2100, with appropriate math coreqs and PHYS 1660L or 2060L; APHY 1510 or MATH 1200; PHYS 4000 (or APHY 1940 with either MATH 2220 or MATH 2250 or MATH 2260).
The major in Applied Physics requires eight courses beyond the introductory sequence.
Two of these must be APHY 4710 and 4720.
All majors are also required to take APHY 3220, APHY 4390 or PHYS 4400, and APHY 4200, or equivalents.
Distribution of courses: 3 advanced courses in physical or mathematical sciences or engineering in area of focus, with DUS approval.
Seniors must complete an independent research project, taken as APHY 4710 and 4720; may be started in the junior year and continued into the senior year.

No more than one course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the requirements of the major with permission of the DUS. The senior special projects, APHY 4710 and 4720, may only be taken for a letter grade.
Courses taken at another institution or during an approved summer or term-time study abroad program may count toward the major requirements with DUS approval.
Substitutions of equivalent courses may be permitted.

constraints.description: With DUS permission, up to three of the seven electives may be substituted with courses from other departments related to the student's research.

senior_requirement.description: A senior research project (ARCG 4491) in some field of archaeology, preferably involving more than one area or discipline.

Standard.description: Complete ARCG 4491 Senior Research Project.

policies.credit_d_fail_note: No more than one course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the requirements of the major.

outside_credit.notes: Courses taken at another institution or during approved study abroad may count toward the major.

other_policies.field_research_required: One intensive summer field school or Yale-affiliated research project required; DUS approval required; costs often subsidized by the Council.
other_policies.elective_distribution: Seven archaeology electives must be drawn from departments with courses multiple-titled with Archaeological Studies; at least three of the seven must be in different departments/programs (Anthropology, Classics, Earth and Planetary Sciences, Environmental Studies, History, History of Art, Near Eastern Languages and Civilizations, Religious Studies).
other_policies.subject_area_reassignment: With DUS permission, a course may be counted toward a subject area other than the one(s) under which it is listed.
other_policies.elective_substitution: With DUS permission, up to three electives may be substituted with courses from other departments in areas related to the student's research.
other_policies.advising: Students should consult with the DUS at the beginning of each term.
other_policies.attributes_link: See attributes indicating courses approved for Archaeological Studies major requirements.

provenance.quote: The major consists of twelve term courses, including the senior project.
Students must participate in a Yale-affiliated summer research project, or that of another archaeological field school approved in advance by the DUS.

The following five courses are required: an introductory survey; the introductory laboratory course ARCG 3116L; an advanced laboratory course; a theory course; and the senior research project ARCG 4491.

The remaining seven courses required for the major must be distributed among the subject areas represented by the departments and programs offering courses multiple-titled with Archaeological Studies, with three of those seven courses found in different departments and programs.
For three of the seven archaeology electives students may, with permission of the DUS, substitute courses from other departments in areas related to their research.
No more than one course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the requirements of the major.
The final requirement for the major is a senior research project (ARCG 4491) in some field of archaeology.

distributions.category: Design: History and theory of architecture and the city electives

constraints.description: See approved attributes and course lists.
See approved attributes and course lists.
See approved attributes and course lists.
See approved attributes and course lists.

distributions.category: History, Theory, Criticism, and Urbanism: History and theory of architecture and the city electives

constraints.description: See approved attributes and course lists.

distributions.category: History, Theory, Criticism, and Urbanism: Additional elective (urbanism and landscape, materials and design, or structures and computation)

constraints.description: See approved attributes and course lists.

senior_requirement.description: Seniors in the Design concentration take ARCH 4000 in the fall and ARCH 4001 in the spring; seniors in the History, Theory, Criticism of Architecture, and Urbanism concentration take ARCH 4900 in the fall and ARCH 4910 in the spring. All seniors must submit a portfolio of their work to the office of the DUS by the end of spring semester; HTC&U portfolios must include the senior essay.

Design.description: Design project proposals are submitted in the fall for review; final projects due as specified by the course instructor.

History, Theory, Criticism of Architectu.description: Senior essay/project proposals submitted in the fall for review; senior essays and projects due in the office of the DUS by early April.

policies.credit_d_fail_note: No course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the requirements of the major.

outside_credit.notes: Courses taken at another institution or during an approved summer or term-time study abroad program may count toward the major requirements.

other_policies.Required orientations — advanced technol: All Architecture students must complete orientation sessions in the advanced technology workshop and materials laboratory; students in ARCH 2000 complete them at the beginning of the spring term of the sophomore year; access to digital media equipment is not allowed until completed.
other_policies.Required orientations — library: All students must complete a ninety-minute introductory library research session at the beginning of the spring term of the sophomore year; failure to complete precludes completion of the major; no substitutions permitted.
other_policies.Required orientations — shop: All majors must complete woodshop and materials lab orientations at the beginning of the fall term in the junior year before the first day of classes; access is not allowed until completed.
other_policies.Declaration of Intent to Major: Must be submitted in the spring term of the sophomore year after taking ARCH 1001, ARCH 2000, and one of ARCH 2103, ARCH 2600, or ARCH 2601; includes a writing sample (e.g., from ARCH 2600) and an encouraged electronic portfolio; acceptance to the major is required.
other_policies.Courses in the School of Architecture: Open to majors and nonmajors with permission of the instructor and the graduate registrar; not available for the Credit/D/Fail option; admission based on previous coursework and performance.
other_policies.Concentrations: Majors must select either the Design concentration or the History, Theory, Criticism of Architecture, and Urbanism concentration.
other_policies.Core completion timing: Majors are expected to complete the core of four courses by the end of their junior year.
other_policies.Elective subject areas: Electives are categorized under history and theory of architecture and the city; urbanism and landscape; materials and design; structures and computation.

provenance.quote: Three courses are prerequisite for all concentrations: ARCH 1001; 2000; and one of the following: ARCH 2103, 2600, or 2601.
Students majoring in Architecture are required to take fifteen course credits, including prerequisites and the senior requirement.
Majors are expected to take the three prerequisites by the end of their sophomore year and to complete a core of four courses, for five course credits, by the end of their junior year.
Design concentration — the studio courses ARCH 3000 and 3001; and the history of architecture surveys, ARCH 2001 and 2003.

History, Theory, Criticism of Architecture, and Urbanism concentration — ARCH 3000; a second design studio or urban laboratory (e.g. ARCH 3301, ARCH 3305) or an elective approved by the DUS; and the history of architecture surveys ARCH 2001 and 2003.
Design concentration electives: 1 in history and theory of architecture and the city; 1 in urbanism and landscape; 1 in materials and design; 1 in structures and computation.

HTC&U concentration electives: 4 in history and theory of architecture and the city; 1 elective in urbanism and landscape, materials and design, or structures and computation, or other relevant course; all approved by DUS.
Seniors in the Design concentration take ARCH 4000 in the fall term and 4001 in the spring term. Seniors in the HTC&U concentration take ARCH 4900 in the fall term and 4910 in the spring term.
All seniors must submit a portfolio of their work to the office of the DUS by the end of spring semester.
Credit/D/Fail — No course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the requirements of the major.
Outside credit — Courses taken at another institution or during an approved summer or term-time study abroad program may count toward the major requirements with DUS approval.
Required orientations — advanced technology, library, and shop

constraints.subject: History of Art
constraints.description: DUS-approved equivalent permitted.

senior_requirement.description: Two-term senior project in Art.

Standard.description: Complete ART 4995 and ART 4996.

policies.credit_d_fail_note: No more than one course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the requirements of the major.

outside_credit.notes: Outside studio art credits may not replace the two prerequisites and are applied at the discretion of the DUS subject to faculty review.

other_policies.course_admission: Art courses are by permission of instructor due to limited class size; priority given to School of Art students and declared Art and Computing and the Arts majors.
other_policies.advising_and_registration: All Art majors must register with the DUS each term and participate in the sophomore review in the fourth term; advising sessions held during registration.
other_policies.materials_costs: Many studio art courses require purchase of some supplies in addition to materials provided.
other_policies.2000_level_substitution: A sixth course numbered 0001–1999 may be counted toward the 2000-level course requirement if five such introductory courses have been completed.
other_policies.repeat_for_credit: Some Art courses may be repeated for credit with permission of both the instructor and the DUS.
other_policies.outside_courses_restriction: Outside studio art credits may not replace the two prerequisites and are applied at the discretion of the DUS subject to faculty review.
other_policies.concentrations: Students select a concentration in graphic design, painting/printmaking, photography, sculpture, or filmmaking; recommended courses vary by area.
other_policies.graphic_design_recommended: ART 1732; ART 2764; ART 2765; ART 2766 or ART 3768; ART 3769 or ART 3770; ART 4768 or ART 4769.
other_policies.painting_printmaking_recommended: ART 1516; ART 1530; ART 3531 or ART 3532; ART 2524; ART 2545 or ART 3556; ART 4514; ART 4532; ART 4533 or ART 4557.
other_policies.photography_recommended: ART 1836 and/or ART 1838; ART 2837 and/or ART 2839; ART 3837 or ART 3838; ART 3879; ART 4801.
other_policies.sculpture_recommended: Any 2 of ART 1610, ART 1620, ART 1621, ART 1622 or ART 1623; and any 3 of ART 2610, ART 3646, ART 3648, ART 3771, or ART 4646.
other_policies.filmmaking_required_courses: ART 1942; ART 3941; ART 3942; and ART 4942 or ART 4943.
other_policies.filmmaking_substitution: In the filmmaking concentration, two non-production Film and Media Studies courses may be substituted for the history of art requirement; substitution in other concentrations only with DUS permission.
other_policies.summer_fellowship: Art majors may apply for the Ellen Battell Stoeckel Fellowship (Norfolk); up to three course credits may be awarded and used toward the major at the discretion of the DUS.

provenance.quote: The prerequisites for acceptance into the major are the sophomore review ... and five introductory courses (courses numbered 0001–1999). Visual Thinking (ART 1111) and Basic Drawing (ART 1514) are mandatory, and may not be waived.

The Art major requires fourteen courses, including ... four courses at the 2000-level or above; ... the Junior Seminar (ART 3995); ... the two-term senior project (ART 4995 and ART 4996); and ... two courses in the history of art, or DUS-approved equivalent.
A student who has completed five courses numbered 0001–1999 may count a sixth such course towards the 2000-level course requirement.
Required courses for the filmmaking concentration are ART 1942, 3941, 3942, and ART 4942 or 4943.
No more than one course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the requirements of the major.
Courses taken at another institution or during an approved summer or term-time study abroad program may count toward the major requirements with DUS approval.
The senior requirement consists of a two-term senior project, ART 4995 and ART 4996.
All Art majors are required to register with the DUS at the beginning of each term ... as well as participate in the sophomore review in the fourth term.

Courses in Art are open to all undergraduate students, but are registered by permission of instructor only due to limited class size; priority is given to School of Art students and declared Art and Computing and the Arts majors.

other_policies.related_courses_encouraged: Candidates are encouraged to take related courses in other departments.

provenance.quote: Candidates for the major complete at least twelve term courses (including the Senior Tutorial).
Of these, two must be in ancient history and/or classical art and archaeology, and two must be in Greek or Latin, or both, numbered 2003 or higher.
Students must also take one course that covers broadly the literature and/or culture of ancient Greece (CLCV at the 1000- or 2000-level) and one ... of ancient Rome (CLCV at the 1000- or 2000-level).
Senior requirement: CLCV 4998 or CLCV 4999, or both; one-term requires an additional course.
Credit/D/Fail: Courses taken Credit/D/Fail may not be counted toward the requirements of the major.

other_policies.enrollment_limit_per_term: Students may only enroll in one college seminar per term.

Undergraduates play a central role in the seminar selection process.

constraints.description: Students must take at least one course in three of five periods: Antiquity; Medieval; Early Modern; 19th century; 20th–21st centuries. A course may count if at least half the primary readings come from the period.
One course must involve a significant component of literary or cultural theory; consult the DUS for applicability of courses offered in other departments.

For in-language literature in a single non-English language, two or three courses are required depending on concentration; one L4 may count, remaining must be at L5 or equivalent. Non-instructional language courses with extensive in-language readings may count; with DUS permission, one requirement may be met with a language course that includes substantial literary readings or film.

senior_requirement.description: Students complete a senior essay in Comparative Literature, either one term or two terms. The essay normally uses texts in their original language; exceptions require DUS approval. Deadlines for proposal, prospectus, draft, and final submission are set by the department. A well-developed project may be pursued as a yearlong essay by petition; the second term may count as one elective toward the major.

One-Term.description: One-term senior essay completed in a single term.

Two-Term.description: Yearlong senior essay; normally CPLT 4920 in one term followed by CPLT 4930 in the next term.

policies.credit_d_fail_note: No more than two courses taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied to the major with DUS permission; specific required courses may not be taken Credit/D/Fail.

outside_credit.notes: Courses taken at another institution or during approved study abroad may count toward the major with DUS approval. One approved international program course may, with DUS permission, be applied to the in-language literature requirement.

other_policies.language_competence: All concentrations require advanced (L5) competence in at least one language other than English.
other_policies.in_language_details: For in-language literature in a single non-English language, two or three courses are required depending on concentration; one L4 may count, remaining must be at L5 or equivalent. Non-instructional language courses with extensive in-language readings may count; with DUS permission, one requirement may be met with a language course that includes substantial literary readings or film.
other_policies.period_definition: Students must take at least one course in three of five periods: Antiquity; Medieval; Early Modern; 19th century; 20th–21st centuries. A course may count if at least half the primary readings come from the period.
other_policies.theory_definition: One course must involve a significant component of literary or cultural theory; consult the DUS for applicability of courses offered in other departments.
other_policies.concentration_structure: Majors choose one concentration (Literature and Comparative Cultures; Intensive Language; Film; Literary Translation); all share the core seminars but have distinct distribution requirements.
other_policies.literature_and_comparative_cultures_requ: Requires three in-language literature courses; three period courses; two electives (one may be creative writing or Directed Studies; ENGL 1014, 1015, 1020 may not be counted); and one theory course.
other_policies.intensive_language_requirements: Requires three in-language literature courses in one non-English language; two literature courses in a second non-English language; and one theory course.
other_policies.film_concentration_requirements: Requires two in-language literature courses in the same non-English language (at least one at L5); three electives with FILM course numbers; and one course in film theory.
other_policies.literary_translation_requirements: Requires three in-language literature courses in one non-English language (two must be L5); one theory course; and two courses in translation studies.
other_policies.study_abroad_in_language: One approved international program course may, with DUS permission, be applied to the in-language literature requirement.
other_policies.course_substitutions: A literature course taught in English translation may count as a non-English literature course if the student completes additional assignments engaging with texts in the original language and submits the instructor-signed form to the DUS at the beginning of the semester.
other_policies.non_native_english_option: Non-native speakers permitted to complete the language distributional requirement via ENGL 1014, 1015, 1020, or 3450 may count three English literature courses toward the in-language literature requirement, or may instead take three courses in a third language.
other_policies.dus_registration: Prospective majors should register with the DUS to develop a coherent sequence of courses suited to their interests.
other_policies.equivalents_note: For Film and Literary Translation concentrations, CPLT 1430 or CPLT 3048 equivalents may be permitted by the DUS.

provenance.quote: The Comparative Literature major requires twelve term courses, including the senior requirement and two required foundational seminars, one of which must be CPLT 1300 and the other may be CPLT 1400 or 1430 or 3048, depending on which concentration the student is pursuing.
Students must take at least one course in three of five historical periods…
For the theory requirement, students must take one course that involves a significant component of literary or cultural theory.
All concentrations of the Comparative Literature major require students to have advanced (L5) competence in at least one language other than English.
The senior essay may be written over one term (CPLT 4910) or over two terms (CPLT 4920, 4930).
Film concentration… three electives (which must have a FILM course number); and one course in film theory.
Credit/D/Fail… No more than two courses… none of the specific required courses may be taken Credit/D/Fail.
Outside credit… may count toward the major requirements with DUS approval.
A literature course taught in English translation is sometimes suitable as a non-English literature course… with additional assignments… submit the form to the DUS.

prerequisites.must_complete_by: end of the fall term of the sophomore year

constraints.description: Depth courses must be chosen from at least two disciplines; with DUS approval, depth courses may be drawn from other fields. Up to two directed reading or research courses may count with permission.
Other courses may fulfill the skills requirement with DUS permission.

senior_requirement.description: A full-credit capstone course in which the senior essay is written; students meet regularly to discuss current work in cognitive science and their developing research projects.

B.S..description: Two half-credit empirical research courses (totaling one course credit); open only to Cognitive Science seniors; letter grade.

B.A..description: Two half-credit nonempirical research courses (totaling one course credit); open only to Cognitive Science seniors; letter grade.

repeat_for_credit_limits.quote_justification: Only one term of CGSC 4710, 4720, 4730, or 4740 may be offered toward the major.

policies.credit_d_fail_note: No course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the major requirements, except with permission of the DUS.

outside_credit.notes: Courses taken at another institution or during an approved summer or term-time study abroad program may count toward the major with DUS approval.

other_policies.double_counting_prohibited: No course may be used to fulfill more than one requirement for the major.
other_policies.skills_timing: One skills course is required, preferably before the senior year.
other_policies.junior_colloquium_credit: CGSC 3950 is a half-credit junior colloquium.
other_policies.senior_courses_access: CGSC 4800, 4810, 4900, and 4910 are only open to Cognitive Science seniors and receive a letter grade.
other_policies.requirement_cohort_policy: Students are held to the requirements in place when they declared the major; with DUS approval, updated requirements for 2025–2026 may be fulfilled by students who declared in a prior term.
other_policies.major_application: Students may apply to enter the major after the first year via an online Qualtrics application including a transcript, a statement of purpose, and a list of six upper-level courses planned for the research focus.
other_policies.program_plan_approval: Selection of courses must be approved by the DUS to ensure overall coherence.
other_policies.depth_substitutions: Depth courses may be drawn from other fields when necessary to explore the student's focal topic, with DUS approval.
other_policies.directed_reading_limit: With DUS permission, up to two directed reading or research courses may count toward the depth requirement.

provenance.quote: An introductory survey course, CGSC 1100, is normally taken by the end of the fall term of the sophomore year.
Fifteen term courses... are required for the major, including the introductory course and the senior requirement.
Each major is required to take a course from four of the following six areas.
Students fulfill a depth requirement by completing six courses... All six depth courses must be intermediate or advanced; for most disciplines, courses numbered 3000 or above fulfill the requirement.
One skills course is required... Courses that fulfill the skills requirement include CPSC 1001, 2020, LING 2249, PSYC 2670, S&DS 1000, 2200, 2300...
In the junior year, students are required to take CGSC 3950, a half-credit colloquium...
Only one term of CGSC 4710, 4720, 4730, or 4740 may be offered toward the major.
No course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the requirements of the major, except with permission of the DUS.
Courses taken at another institution or during an approved summer or term-time study abroad program may count toward the major requirements with DUS approval.
In the senior year, students take a full-credit capstone course... Students must take this course during their senior year.
B.S.—CGSC 4900 and CGSC 4910; B.A.—CGSC 4800 and CGSC 4810.
The particular selection of courses must be approved by the director of undergraduate studies (DUS) in order to assure overall coherence.

distributions.category: Intersection of Computer Science and Economics

constraints.description: Complete one of the following sequences: (1) ECON 1117 and ECON 2123; (2) ECON 2135 and ECON 2136; or (3) S&DS 2410 and S&DS 2420 and ECON 2136 (S&DS 2410 and 2420 may be taken instead of ECON 2135).
S&DS 2410 and S&DS 2420 may be taken instead of ECON 2135; ECON 2136 is still required.

senior_requirement.description: CSEC 4910 is a one-term independent project that explicitly combines techniques and subject matter from computer science and economics; proposal must be approved by the academic adviser and project adviser and signed by the DUS by the end of the third week of the term.

Standard.description: Independent-project course integrating computer science and economics.

policies.credit_d_fail_note: No course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the requirements of the major.

outside_credit.notes: At most two outside courses may count for a term abroad or summer; at most three for a year abroad; outside courses may not be counted toward intermediate microeconomics, econometrics, or the intersection of computer science and economics.

other_policies.advising: Course schedules must be approved by an academic adviser and signed by the DUS each term; students should meet with the DUS and advisers during registration.
other_policies.distinction_in_major: Distinction requires grades of A or A– in at least three quarters of courses in the major (excluding prerequisites) and a senior project judged worthy of distinction.
other_policies.intersection_course_double_counting: The intersection course may not also count as one of the five electives or for the game theory requirement.
other_policies.searchable_attributes: YC CSEC Elective not CS or EC; YC CSEC Elctv intrsectn CS/EC
other_policies.approval_requirements_advanced_course_su: With DUS and academic adviser permission, a more advanced course in the same area may substitute for a required course.
other_policies.approval_requirements_related_department: With academic adviser permission, one or two electives may be taken in related departments not usually serving as electives in Computer Science or Economics.

provenance.quote: The B.S. degree program requires successful completion of fourteen term courses (not including courses taken to satisfy prerequisites) and the senior project.

The required courses include CPSC 2010; 2230; 3230; 3650 or 3660; ECON 2121 or 2125; two courses in econometrics (ECON 1117 and 2123 or ECON 2135 and ECON 2136); one course in game theory ECON 3351 or CPSC 4550; one course in the intersection of computer science and economics.
S&DS 2410 and 2420 may be taken instead of ECON 2135.

Elective courses are essentially those courses that count as electives in the Computer Science major, the Economics major, or both... At least two electives must be taken in the Computer Science department, and at least one must be taken in the Economics department.
In the senior year, each student must complete CSEC 4910... proposal must be approved... and signed by the DUS by the end of the third week of the term.
No course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the requirements of the major.
Courses taken at another institution or during an approved summer or term-time study abroad program may count toward the major requirements with DUS approval.

Students... may petition... at most two courses from outside Yale for a term abroad or summer; at most three for a year abroad; not counted toward intermediate microeconomics, econometrics, or the intersection of computer science and economics.

Computer Science and Economics majors may earn Distinction in the Major if they receive grades of A or A– in at least three quarters of their courses in the major... and their senior-project advisers determine that their senior projects are worthy of distinction.

senior_requirement.description: A project or an essay on a topic acceptable to both departments; students typically enroll in CPSC 4900 or MATH 4750. Written permission from both DUS is required before embarking.

policies.credit_d_fail_note: No course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the requirements of the major.

outside_credit.notes: Courses taken after matriculation at Yale at another institution or during an approved summer or term-time study abroad program may count toward the major requirements with DUS approval.

other_policies.course_listings: A course must be listed with a MATH number to count toward mathematics requirements and must be listed with a CPSC number to count toward computer science requirements; substitutions from other departments are not allowed.
other_policies.math_substitution: With prior written permission from the Mathematics DUS, students who completed multivariable calculus during high school may substitute a higher-level mathematics course in the same area for MATH 1200.
other_policies.graduate_math_courses: Graduate mathematics courses level 5000–5999 may be counted as electives; graduate mathematics courses level 6000 or above may not be counted.
other_policies.program_approval: The entire program of each student must be approved by the DUS in each department.

provenance.quote: Prerequisites None
The major requires fourteen term courses as well as a senior project.

Six of the fourteen courses must be in computer science: CPSC 2010; CPSC 2230; CPSC 3230; and CPSC 3650 or 3660; one advanced course with significant mathematical content; and one additional advanced course other than CPSC 4900.
Only one of CPSC 3650 and 3660 may be taken for major credit.
The remaining eight courses must be in mathematics: MATH 1200, either MATH 2250 or 2260, MATH 2440, and five additional term courses numbered 2250-4690.

A course must be listed with a MATH number to count toward the mathematics requirements and must be listed with a CPSC number to count toward the computer science requirements—substitutions from other departments are not allowed.
Graduate mathematics courses level 5000-5999 may be counted as electives; graduate mathematics courses level 6000 or above may not be counted.
Credit/D/Fail No course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the requirements of the major.

Outside credit Courses taken after matriculation at Yale at another institution or during an approved summer or term-time study abroad program may count toward the major requirements with DUS approval.

The senior requirement is a project or an essay on a topic acceptable to both departments. Students typically enroll in CPSC 4900 or MATH 4750. Permission must be obtained in writing from the DUS of both departments before embarking on the project or the essay.
The entire program of each student majoring in Computer Science and Mathematics must be approved by the DUS in each department.

PSYC Natural Science point of view

senior_requirement.description: Students must complete a senior project in either Computer Science or Psychology; the project must be approved by the DUS in each department.

policies.credit_d_fail_note: No Computer Science course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the major; no more than one Psychology course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the major; no 200-level Psychology course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the major.

outside_credit.notes: Courses taken at another institution or during approved study abroad may count toward the major.

other_policies.ap_exemption_psyc_1100: Students with a score of 5 on the AP Psychology exam are exempt from PSYC 1100.
other_policies.cs_ai_exclusions: CPSC 2800 and CPSC 4900 may not be counted among the advanced AI courses.
other_policies.cs_course_count_requirement: Eight of the fourteen required courses must be in Computer Science.
other_policies.ai_substitution_policy: With permission of both DUSs, a highly relevant cognitive psychology or cognitive science course may substitute for one AI course.
other_policies.psych_core_reference: Refer to Psychology program overview for courses designated as Core and for social vs natural science categories.
other_policies.program_approval_by_dus: Entire program must be approved by the DUS in each department.
other_policies.ai_substitution_requires_dus_approval: With permission of both DUSs, a relevant course in cognitive psychology or cognitive science not counted among the six PSYC courses may substitute for one AI course.

provenance.quote: Prerequisite: PSYC 1100; students who have scored 5 on the AP Psychology exam are exempt.
Eight of the fourteen required courses must be in computer science: CPSC 2010, 2020, 2230, 3230, and CPSC 3650 or 3660, and three advanced computer science courses in artificial intelligence.
MATH 2440 may substitute for CPSC 2020.
CPSC 2800 and 4900 may not be counted as one of these courses.

The remaining six courses for the psychology requirement include one course in statistics (S&DS 1000 or S&DS 2300) and at least one course in research methods from PSYC 2100–2990; at least two psychology courses from the social science point of view; and at least two courses from the natural science point of view.
At least one of the two psychology courses from both the social science point of view and the natural science point of view must be designated as Core.

With the permission of both DUSs, a course in cognitive psychology or cognitive science that is highly relevant to the major and not counted among the six PSYC courses may substitute for one AI course.
Senior Requirement: Students must take either CPSC 4900 or PSYC 4990, and the project must be approved by the DUS in each department.

No course in Computer Science taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the requirements of the major; no more than one course in psychology taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the major requirements; no 200-level psychology course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the major requirements.
Outside credit may count toward the major requirements with DUS approval.
The entire program of each student must be approved by the DUS in each department.

senior_requirement.description: No senior requirement specified.

policies.credit_d_fail_note: No course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the requirements of the certificate.

other_policies.Double-counting restriction: Students may not use any of the five required courses to satisfy the requirements of any major or other certificate.
other_policies.Substitution rule: If a required course is required for another program, the student must substitute another course from the same category or a more advanced one for the Programming Certificate.
other_policies.No overlapping within certificate: No course may be used to satisfy more than one of the five required courses.
other_policies.Eligibility restriction: Majors in Computer Science, and in the joint programs with Economics, Electrical Engineering, Mathematics, and Psychology, or in Computing and the Arts may not pursue the Certificate.
other_policies.Prerequisite alternatives: Prerequisite may also be satisfied by S115 or successful completion of an AP Computer Science course.
other_policies.Advising and exceptions: Advised by Ozan Erat; exceptions to requirements are limited.

provenance.quote: The Certificate in Programming prepares students to program computers in support of work in any area of study.
Prerequisite: CPSC 1100, 1001, S115 or successful completion of an AP Computer Science course.
Programming—One from CPSC 2010 or CPSC 2000; Data structures CPSC 2230; Advanced programming—One from CPSC 3270 or CPSC 3230.
A programming elective ... such as CPSC 4180, 4210, 4230, 4240, 4330, CPSC 4381, 4390, 4460, or 4780 ... or a second course that satisfies the advanced programming requirement.
An applications or algorithms elective ... such as CPSC 3340, 3760, 4310, 4320, 4740, 4770, 4790, or LING 3800 ... or a course in algorithms (such as CPSC 3650 or 3660).
Credit/D/Fail—No course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the requirements of the certificate.

provenance.quote: B.A. degree program requires 11 term credits beyond the prerequisites and not including the senior requirement.
B.S. degree program requires 14 term credits beyond the prerequisites and not including the senior requirement.
Both degree students must take CPSC 2010 and 2230.
Proof-based discrete mathematics: one of MATH 2440, LING 2249, or CPSC 2020; linear algebra: MATH 2220 or MATH 2250.
B.A. statistics core: S&DS 2380.
B.S. statistics core: (1) one of S&DS 2400 or 2410 together with S&DS 2420; or (2) S&DS 2380 and either S&DS 2300 or any S&DS course numbered 2420 or above.
Linguistics core courses LING 2320, 2530, 2630; B.A. take 2 of 3; B.S. take all 3.
Advanced courses: one advanced linguistic structure (LING 3350, 3540, 3640); one NLP (CPSC 4770 or LING 2270); one machine learning (S&DS 2650, 3650, or CPSC 3810).
Electives may be satisfied by pre-approved courses listed on the Computing and Linguistics website; other relevant courses may satisfy with DUS approval.
No course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the requirements of the major (other than as prerequisites).

All majors enroll in capstone seminar CSLI 4900 in the fall; B.A. complete senior project as part of CSLI 4900; B.S. continue work on senior project in the spring; B.S. senior project must involve independent research.

senior_requirement.description: No senior requirement in this program.

other_policies.admission: Approximately ten percent of the first-year class are accepted; acceptance required to enroll

provenance.quote: Directed Studies (DS), a selective program for first-year students
Directed Studies has no prerequisites
Students must enroll in the full slate of Directed Studies courses in both semesters of the program.
In order to enroll for the second term, students must have completed the first term's courses.
The Directed Studies program consists of three integrated full-year courses in Literature, Philosophy, and Historical and Political Thought.
Directed Studies fulfills ... the two required course credits in the humanities and arts (HU), ... the social sciences (SO), and ... writing (WR).
Approximately ten percent of the first-year class are accepted each year.
Courses taken in Directed Studies can be counted toward satisfying requirements in a variety of majors.

provenance.quote: Twelve term courses are required beyond the prerequisites, not including the two-term senior project.

Students choose a concentration in architecture, art, history of art, music, or theater, dance, and performance studies.

The entire program of each student majoring in Computing and the Arts must be approved by the DUS.

The prerequisites include mathematics (MATH 1150), biology (BIOL 1010 and BIOL 1020 or EPS 2550), or physics (PHYS 1700, 1710; or PHYS 1800, 1810; or PHYS 2000, 2010), and a lecture course in chemistry.
The major requirements consist of at least nine term courses, beyond the prerequisites.
These include two courses in EPS numbered 1000–1400, with any accompanying laboratories.
Courses in natural resources (EPS 2740 or EPS 2750) and geochemical processes (EPS 2200 or EPS 2320 or EPS 2610 or EPS 3100).
Five additional courses at the 2000 level or higher in Earth and Planetary Sciences or related fields, approved by the DUS, including either the senior essay or the senior thesis.

Three courses are required in literature in translation, taught in English, selected from EALL 2000–3999; one must be focused primarily on premodern content.

other_policies.env_energy_core: Core chosen from EPS 2320, EPS 2550, EPS 2740, EPS 2750, EPS 3100, EPS 2100 or 2200 or 3120, EPS 3220, EPS 3620; at least two electives must be from EPS.
other_policies.paleontology_core: Take EPS 1250 and 1260L; four core courses from areas including sedimentary processes (EPS 2320 or 3550), evolution (EEB 2225), vertebrate and invertebrate paleontology (EPS 2700 or 3250 or 3750; EPS 3130), paleoecology (EPS 3450), microbiology (EPS 2550), carbon cycle and climate (EPS 3100 or 4020), and statistical analysis; at least four upper-level (2000+) paleontology courses; at least one elective must be from EPS.
other_policies.solid_earth_core: Core chosen from EPS 2100 or 2120 or 3500; EPS 2200; EPS 2320; EPS 3100; EPS 3120; at least two electives must be from EPS.

provenance.quote: B.S. program ... choose from four concentrations: Atmosphere, Ocean, and Climate; Environmental and Energy Geoscience; Paleontology and Geobiology; and Solid Earth Science.

Atmosphere, Ocean, and Climate prerequisites: ENAS 1300 or equivalent; ENAS 1940; PHYS 1800, 1810 and PHYS 2050L, 2060L.

Environmental and Energy Geoscience prerequisites ... physics (PHYS 1700, 1710; or PHYS 1800, 1810; or PHYS 2000, 2010), or ... cellular biology (BIOL 1010 and 1020, or MCDB 120) and evolutionary biology (BIOL 1030 and 1040 or EPS 1250 and 1260L).
Paleontology and Geobiology prerequisites ... college-level biology (BIOL 1010–1040), or CHEM 1650 or CHEM 1670, and mathematics.
Solid Earth Science prerequisites ... CHEM 1650 or CHEM 1670, physics (PHYS 1700, 1710; or PHYS 1800, 1810; or PHYS 2000, 2010), and mathematics.
To begin study ... majors take an introductory course in EPS, selected from EPS 1000; EPS 1010; EPS 1100 with 1110L; or EPS 1250 with 1260L.

Number of courses: Atmosphere, Ocean, and Climate, Environmental and Energy Geoscience, and Solid Earth Science concentrations—at least 11 courses; Paleontology and Geobiology concentration—at least 12 courses, for 11.5 credits.
Senior requirement: senior essay (EPS 4920) or, with permission of faculty, two-term senior thesis (EPS 4900, 4910).
No course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied to the prerequisites or the requirements of the major.

provenance.quote: The prerequisite to the major is completion of study at the L2 level of an East Asian language taught at Yale or the equivalent.
Beyond the prerequisite, the major consists of thirteen course credits, which may include up to six taken in a preapproved program of study abroad.
Beyond the prerequisite, the major consists of thirteen course credits, which may include up to six taken in a preapproved program of study abroad.
Six course credits must be taken in East Asian language courses, including a course at the L4 level and one year of advanced study (L5) with readings in the East Asian language.
Beyond the language requirement, the major includes seven course credits, six in the country or area of focus and one outside it.
Beyond the language requirement, the major includes seven course credits, six in the country or area of focus and one outside it.
Of the course credits in the area of focus, one must be in the premodern period, at least two must be seminars, and one is the senior requirement.
Of the course credits in the area of focus, one must be in the premodern period, at least two must be seminars, and one is the senior requirement.
Before enrolling in the course in which the senior requirement will be met, students must have completed the two seminars related to their area of focus requirement.

Students may take a seminar that relates to the country or area of focus, culminating in a senior thesis. Students who are unable to write a senior essay in a seminar may complete a one-term senior essay in EAST 4900, or a one-credit, two-term senior research project in EAST 4910, EAST 4920.

provenance.quote: The major has prerequisites in both mathematics and economics: MATH 1200; ECON 1110 or 1115; and ECON 1111 or 1116.

One intermediate microeconomics course (ECON 2125 is preferred, but ECON 2121 is also acceptable) and one intermediate macroeconomics course (ECON 2126 is preferred, but ECON 2122 is also acceptable).
Two mathematical economics courses, ECON 3351 or 4425 and one of ECON 3350, 4417, or 4433.
Two courses in econometrics, ECON 2135 (or equivalent) and ECON 2136. ECON 2135 can be replaced by S&DS 2410 and 2420...
One proof-based linear algebra course (MATH 2250 or 2260) and one real analysis course (MATH 2550 or 2560).
Students must take either a senior seminar in mathematics, MATH 4800 or 4810, or an Economic theory seminar, designated as YC ECON Theory Seminar in Yale Course Search.

other_policies.enrollment_limit: Enrollment limited to fifteen or eighteen students depending on the course.

provenance.quote: The First-Year Seminar Program offers a diverse array of courses open only to first-year students.

Special permission is required for exceptions which must be approved by the Director of the First-Year Seminar Program.
Auditing is not permitted in first-year seminars.

constraints.description: Area of interest courses do not include the senior essay or project.

senior_requirement.description: Complete either a yearlong senior essay/project with ER&M 4091 (fall colloquium) and ER&M 4092 (spring senior project seminar), or complete two upper-level ER&M seminars and write a 20–25 page final paper in one seminar with instructor approval.

policies.credit_d_fail_note: No more than two courses taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the major with permission of the DUS. ER&M 3000 and courses counting toward the senior requirement may not be taken Credit/D/Fail.

outside_credit.notes: Courses taken at another institution or during an approved summer or term-time study abroad program may count toward the major.

other_policies.study_abroad: Students are encouraged to undertake a term abroad and should consult the DUS to identify courses that may count.
other_policies.community_learning: Students are encouraged to engage in community-based learning opportunities.

Students may take up to two courses required for the major in other departments ... These courses must be approved by the DUS.
Majors may choose a yearlong senior essay or project ... ER&M 4091 ... and ... ER&M 4092.
Alternatively, students may take two upper-level ER&M seminars, and in one ... write a final paper of 20–25 pages ... These seminars may be taken during either the fall or spring term.

Enrollment in the major requires permission of the DUS before the beginning of the fall term of the junior year.

distributions.category: Core seminars from core areas (Ethics, Politics, Economics)

senior_requirement.description: A senior essay within the student’s area of concentration, reflecting extensive research and appropriate methodology; may be written as a one-term or yearlong independent study or within a relevant seminar with adviser and DUS approval.

policies.credit_d_fail_note: No more than one course taken Cr/D/F may be applied to the major, excluding the seminar in which the senior essay is written.

outside_credit.notes: Courses taken at another institution or during approved study abroad may count toward the major with DUS approval.

other_policies.senior_essay_deadlines: Fall term senior essays due early December; spring term and yearlong essays due mid-April.
other_policies.senior_essay_length: One-term essays normally 40–50 pages; yearlong essays normally 80–100 pages.

The major requires that students take three core courses: one course selected from EP&E 3212, 3213, 3214, 3215, 3216, or 3217 and two additional core courses from the major’s three core areas… one of which must be an advanced seminar anchored in at least two of the major’s three core areas.

Areas of concentration… must consist of three courses appropriate to the theme, including the seminar or independent study course in which the senior essay is written… At most, one of these three courses may be a lecture course.
A senior essay is required… Students may enroll in EP&E 4491… or in EP&E 4492 and EP&E 4493… Alternatively, students may write their essay within a relevant seminar… with approval of the DUS.
No more than one course taken Cr/D/F may be applied to the requirements of the major, excluding the seminar in which the senior essay is written.

program_name: Food, Agriculture, and Climate Change Certificate

outside_credit.requires: Consult the certificate director before considering such courses.
outside_credit.notes: Courses taken outside regular fall and spring semesters (e.g., summer or year abroad) can provisionally count.

Environment (climate change): 1 required course; search YC Food Environment in Yale Course Search.

provenance.quote: The B.S. degree program has prerequisites in mathematics, chemistry, life sciences, and a natural science lab.

The prerequisites include a term course in mathematics, physics, or statistics selected from MATH 1120 or higher, or PHYS 1700 or higher, or S&DS 1000 or higher, or completion of the Certificate in Data Science.
The two-term lecture sequence in chemistry or one term of CHEM 1670 or higher; the two-credit BIOL sequence BIOL 1010, 1020, 1030 and 1040, or EPS 1250; and a natural science lab.
It is recommended but not required that students complete the prerequisites by the end of their sophomore year.
In addition to the prerequisites, the B.S. degree requires at least twelve course credits.
Two core courses in the humanities or social sciences and two natural science core courses.

For the B.S. degree, two of the six courses must provide interdisciplinary context and three of the six courses must have the science (SC) distributional designation. Of the three SC-designated concentration courses, at least two must have departmental numerical ratings of 1250 or higher.
For the B.S. degree, students complete two terms of EVST 4960.
No course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the requirements of the major, including prerequisites.
Courses taken at another institution or during an approved summer or term-time study abroad program may count toward the major requirements with DUS approval.

Majors may count no more than two courses in the FREN 1800–1999 range. No more than two courses conducted entirely in English (Group C) may count toward the major.

Translation concentration students should sign up for FREN 4920 ... or for FREN 4950 and FREN 4960 ...

Credit/D/Fail No more than one course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the requirements of the major.

At least two of the six courses, including at least one at the 3000-level or above, must include substantial methods training and/or a practical ethnographic component.

distributions.category: Global health competency areas (choose four of six)

other_policies.competency_areas: Electives must fulfill four of the six global health competency areas.

The requirement includes both critical writing and work in images; creative projects include an accompanying critical paper (~15 pages). Students writing a senior essay must also take a course with at least a small production assignment.

Senior Essay—Seminar plus FILM 4920.description: Combine one single-term senior-level seminar with one term of independent research; final essay ~35 pages.

Two-term Documentary Film Workshop plus senior project credit; project counts for three credits total (workshop two terms plus project credit).

Two-term Advanced Fiction Film Workshop plus senior project credit; project counts for three credits total (workshop two terms plus project credit).

policies.credit_d_fail_note: No more than one course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the major with permission of the DUS.

outside_credit.notes: Courses taken at another institution or during approved summer or term-time study abroad may count toward the major with DUS approval.

other_policies.deadlines_website: See the Film and Media Studies website for dates and deadlines for the senior requirement.
other_policies.second_reader: A second reader assigned by the DUS participates in evaluating senior essays and projects.
other_policies.intensive_major: Intensive major requires both a senior project in production and a senior essay; students must request approval at the end of junior year.
other_policies.language_study: Study of relevant languages is urged; students considering graduate work should become proficient in French or another modern language.

provenance.quote: The Film and Media Studies major consists of twelve term courses, including the senior requirement.
Students are required to take FILM 1501, FILM 1601 and FILM 3201, preferably by the end of their sophomore year.

One upper-level course in non-American national cinema designated by attribute YC FILM World Cinema; one upper-level critical studies course (YC FILM Critical Studies); at least one production course (YC FILM Production).
Credit/D/Fail: No more than one course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the requirements of the major with permission of the DUS.
Outside credit may count toward the major requirements with DUS approval.
During the senior year, each student takes one or two senior-level seminars or the equivalent and submits a senior essay or senior project.
Senior essay options: two senior-level seminars, or FILM 4910 and 4920, or one seminar plus FILM 4910 or 4920.
Senior project options include FILM 4550/4560 or FILM 4830/4840 plus FILM 4930 or 4940 (three credits total), FILM 4870/4880, or FILM 4930/4940 with approved petition.

A second reader assigned by the DUS participates in evaluating the essays and/or projects.

distributions.category: Additional GMAN upper-level courses (Groups B & C)

senior_requirement.description: A guided senior essay tutorial culminating in an approximately thirty-page essay, written in English or German, under faculty supervision.

policies.credit_d_fail_note: No more than two courses taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the major, with permission of the DUS.

outside_credit.notes: Courses taken at another institution or during approved study abroad may count toward the major requirements.

other_policies.study_abroad_credit_limits: One term abroad: up to two courses; academic year abroad: up to four courses, with DUS approval.

other_policies.group_b_counting: No restriction on the number of Group B courses that may count toward the major, provided all requirements are met.

other_policies.substitutions_note: With DUS approval, some substitutions and exceptions may be possible.

provenance.quote: Prerequisite to the major are first- and second-year German or the equivalent.
The requirements of the major in German Studies consist of ten term courses, including the senior essay.
All majors must complete at least one GMAN course numbered in the 1500s, one in the 1600s, and one in the 1700s, plus six additional courses numbered GMAN 1600 and above.
No more than two courses taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the requirements of the major, with permission of the DUS.
Seniors in the standard German Studies major enroll in GMAN 4920, a guided senior essay tutorial course.
Intensive major: two-term senior essay (GMAN 4920 and GMAN 4930) replacing one advanced seminar.
Students who study abroad for one term may count up to two courses toward the major; for an academic year, up to four courses, with approval of the DUS.

Approved electives carry the YC GLBL elective attribute.

Senior Essay Course.description: Senior essay completed in the global affairs senior essay course; may be taken in fall or spring of senior year.

policies.credit_d_fail_note: No course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied to the requirements of the major, except a Cr grade in an L4 language course may be used to demonstrate proficiency in a foreign language.

Students are also required to take two courses in quantitative analysis: GLBL 2121 and GLBL 2122; GLBL 2121 and GLBL 2122 may not count as electives.

provenance.quote: Twelve term courses are required to complete the major: two introductory courses at the 1000 level; four intermediate and advanced courses at the 2000 and 3000 levels; two seminars at the 3500–4497 level; a methods seminar, HSAR 4401; two electives; and the senior essay, HSAR 4499.

constraints.attribute: Preindustrial (before mid-19th century; no later than 1900)

senior_requirement.description: Seniors complete an original research project under a faculty adviser, either as a one-term essay or a two-term essay/project; the two-term option is required for Distinction.

One-term senior essay.description: Independent one-term essay in the fall (or by arrangement in spring); not eligible for Distinction or prizes; counts as one course credit.

Two-term senior essay.description: Independent two-term essay; typical length 40–50 pages; required for eligibility for Distinction.

Alternative two-term senior project.description: Approved non-traditional project based on extensive primary/secondary research plus ~5,000-word historical writing; eligible for Distinction.

other_policies.global_requirement: Global concentration requires 1 course in 5 of 6 regions (Africa, Asia, Europe, Latin America, Middle East/North Africa, United States/Canada), plus 2 preindustrial courses and 2 departmental seminars
other_policies.specialist_requirement: Specialist concentration requires at least 5 (up to 8) courses in a specific region or thematic pathway, at least 2 courses outside the specialization, coverage across at least 3 regions, plus 2 preindustrial courses and 2 departmental seminars
