other_policies.distinction: Distinction in the Major requires A or A– on the two-term senior essay and requisite grades in remaining coursework; students who do not complete the two-term essay are not eligible
other_policies.outside_courses: Up to two non-departmental courses may count toward the major with DUS approval and may fulfill geographic/pathway/preindustrial distributions but not the departmental seminar or senior requirements
other_policies.design_specialization: Specialist concentration students may design an area of specialization with approval of a faculty adviser and the DUS

provenance.quote: Prerequisite: The prerequisite for the major is two term courses in History. (Directed Studies history and philosophy courses count automatically as history prerequisites.)
Twelve term courses in History are required, including prerequisites and the senior requirement.
The global concentration requires one course in five of the six different geographic regions… Students must also take two preindustrial courses… and two 3000-level departmental seminars.

The specialist concentration requires at least five (and up to eight) courses… at least two courses outside their area of specialization, and… at least three geographic regions… Like students in the global concentration, students in the specialist concentration must take two preindustrial courses, and at least two 3000-level departmental seminars.
Courses that begin with the number 3 are departmental seminars… Courses that begin with the number 4 are senior requirement courses and independent studies.
History majors may count up to two lecture courses or non-3000 seminars taken Cr/D/F… Departmental seminars may not be taken Cr/D/F.
Course substitution: History majors are permitted to include up to two courses taught outside the department… Non-departmental courses… may not fulfill Departmental Seminar or senior requirements.

Senior Requirement… one-term senior essay (HIST 4997) or two-term senior essay (HIST 4995 and 4996)… Alternative senior essay option… two-semester projects only… eligible for distinction in the major.
Distinction in the major: Students who receive an A or A– on the two-term senior essay… are awarded Distinction.

senior_requirement.description: In fall or spring of the senior year, majors must present a departmental essay written in Italian under a faculty adviser, enroll in ITAL 4491, meet with the DUS at least twice per month, adhere to prospectus and draft timelines, submit the final version at least 10 days before the last day of classes, and participate in a meeting with department faculty to discuss the thesis and their overall experience.

provenance.quote: Prerequisite: ITAL 1300 (L3) or equivalent by the end of their sophomore year.
The major consists of eleven term courses beyond the prerequisite.
Eight term courses in the Italian Studies department numbered 1400 or above (including graduate courses) are required, at least five of which must be conducted in Italian.

The courses in the department must include ITAL 1400 or equivalent, either ITAL 1500 or 1510, a survey course on Italian literature (ITAL 4162 or 4172), and a course on Dante's Divine Comedy (ITAL 1310 or equivalent).

Students are required to elect two courses in other languages and literatures, history of art, history, linguistics, philosophy, or media related to their field of study and approved by the DUS; any graduate course in another national literature or in linguistics may be substituted for one of these two courses.
In the fall or spring of the senior year, all majors must present a departmental essay written in Italian and completed under the direction of a faculty adviser in ITAL 4491.

other_policies.count_non_program_courses: Courses not listed in program offerings but with at least one-third content on Latin America may count with DUS approval.

provenance.quote: Prerequisite to declaring the major is knowledge of either Spanish or Portuguese at the L3 level. Equivalent placement determined by the placement examination also fulfills the prerequisite.

The major itself requires twelve term courses: one introductory course approved by the DUS; seven courses related to Latin America from departmental offerings; three additional electives; and the senior essay LAST 4491 or senior project LAST 4492.
One of the twelve courses must be taught in Spanish or Portuguese at the L5 level.

The seven Latin American content courses should include ... two courses in the social sciences ... two courses in history; two courses in Spanish American or Brazilian literatures beyond the language requirement; one course in art, architecture, film and media studies, music, or theater studies.
Students must enroll in three seminars or upper-level courses during their junior and senior years. Elective seminars must be approved by the DUS.
Credit/D/Fail: No more than one course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the major requirements.
Outside credit: Courses taken at another institution or during an approved summer or term-time study abroad program may count toward the major requirements with DUS approval.
Senior Requirement: The senior requirement is a research paper written usually in one term in LAST 4491 or a senior project in LAST 4492.

constraints.description: One course each in any two foundational areas other than phonology and syntax: phonetics; morphology; semantics/pragmatics; computational linguistics; language and mind/brain; historical linguistics.
Two additional courses beyond the introductory level in one of the eight areas of linguistics.

constraints.others_with_approval_of: DUS approval required for electives from related programs; more than two foreign language courses require DUS approval to count beyond two.
constraints.description: Additional courses relating to linguistics; may be taken in Linguistics or related programs.

senior_requirement.description: Students attend a research colloquium and write a senior essay during the final spring term.

Standard.description: Senior essay and research colloquium in LING 4910.

policies.credit_d_fail_note: No courses taken Credit/D/Fail, Pass/Fail, or any scale other than the standard letter-grade scale may be applied toward the major without specific DUS approval.

outside_credit.notes: Courses taken at another institution or during approved study abroad may count toward the major with DUS approval.

other_policies.electives_approval: Electives from related programs require DUS approval; no more than two foreign language courses can count without specific DUS approval.
other_policies.ba_ma_option: Exceptionally able students may pursue a simultaneous B.A./M.A.; consult the DUS prior to the sixth term.

provenance.quote: The major requires twelve term courses in linguistics and related areas.
All majors must take one course in the areas of phonology (LING 2320) and syntax (LING 2530).
At least one course must be taken in any two of the six remaining foundational areas of linguistics.

provenance.field: major_requirements.distributions: Depth in a foundational area
provenance.quote: In one of the eight areas of linguistics, students must take two additional courses beyond the introductory level.
Four additional courses relating to linguistics are required, at least one of which must be at the 2000 level or above.
LING 4900, Research Methods in Linguistics, is required.
Students attend a research colloquium and write a senior essay in LING 4910 during the final spring term of the senior year.
No courses taken Credit/D/Fail, Pass/Fail, or any scale other than the standard letter-grade scale, may be applied toward the requirements of the major without specific DUS approval.
Courses taken at another institution or during an approved summer or term-time study abroad program may count toward the major requirements with DUS approval.

constraints.subject: PHYS
constraints.description: Chosen in consultation with the adviser for the major; includes senior requirement

senior_requirement.description: Senior project on a topic appropriate for the combined major and acceptable to both the Physics and Mathematics departments.

Standard.description: Complete a senior project in PHYS 4710 or PHYS 4720.

policies.credit_d_fail_note: No course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the requirements of the major, including the prerequisites.

outside_credit.notes: Courses taken after matriculation at Yale at another institution or during approved study abroad may count toward the major with DUS approval.

other_policies.math_course_listing_only: A course must be listed with a MATH number to count toward mathematics requirements; substitutions from other departments are not allowed.
other_policies.graduate_course_counting: Graduate MATH courses 5000–5999 may count toward undergraduate major requirements; MATH 6000+ may not count toward undergraduate major requirements but can earn graduation credit.
other_policies.prereq_substitution: With prior written permission from the Mathematics DUS, students with high school multivariable calculus may substitute a higher-level MATH course for MATH 1200; the substituted course does not count toward the total number of term courses for the major.
other_policies.physics_prereq_alternatives: Students who completed PHYS 1700/1710 or PHYS 1650L/1660L may enter the major with permission of the Physics DUS.
other_policies.requirement_version_policy: Students are held to the requirements in place when they declared, but may fulfill updated requirements with DUS approval.

provenance.quote: Prerequisites include MATH 1200, an introductory physics lecture sequence numbered PHYS 1800, PHYS 1810 or above, and the introductory laboratory course PHYS 2050L.
Students who have taken PHYS 1700, PHYS 1710, or PHYS 1650L, PHYS 1660L, may also enter the major with permission of the Physics DUS.
Beyond the prerequisites, the major requires fifteen term courses for 14.5 credits, above the introductory level, including PHYS 2060L and the senior project.

At least six of these must be mathematics courses numbered 2220–4690, and at least six must be advanced physics courses (including the senior requirement) chosen in consultation with the adviser for the major.
A senior project in PHYS 4710 or PHYS 4720 on a topic appropriate for the combined major and acceptable to both the Physics and the Mathematics departments is also required.
No course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the requirements of the major, including the prerequisites.
Graduate mathematics courses level 5000–5999 may be counted as electives; graduate mathematics courses level 6000 or above may not be counted.

constraints.description: Select at least three from the core set (examples include Hebrew Bible, rabbinic literature or ancient Judaism, JDST 2000, JDST 2001, Jewish thought, and a survey course in Hebrew and Jewish literature).
Complete either HEBR 1100 and HEBR 1200, or two courses in Hebrew literature in translation.

Two areas selected; three courses in each area chosen in consultation with the DUS, including one introductory course, one junior-year seminar, and one course requiring a final research paper; one relevant course should be outside Jewish Studies.

senior_requirement.description: Complete either a two-term senior essay related to both focus areas or a one-term senior essay related to one focus area plus an additional seminar related to the other.

Two-term senior essay.description: Two-term senior essay related to both areas of focus.

One-term senior essay plus additional se.description: One-term senior essay related to one area of focus and an additional seminar related to the other.

policies.credit_d_fail_note: No more than one course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the major requirements.

outside_credit.notes: Courses taken at another institution or during an approved summer or term-time study abroad program may count toward the major requirements with DUS approval.

other_policies.Hebrew language counting: Up to three Hebrew language courses may be counted toward the requirements of the major.
other_policies.Outside course in focus areas: One relevant course should be in an area outside Jewish Studies.
other_policies.Designing focus areas: With DUS approval, students may design their own areas of focus.
other_policies.Advising: Students considering a major in Jewish Studies should contact the DUS as early as possible.
other_policies.Study abroad: Students majoring in Jewish Studies should be aware of numerous opportunities for study abroad and consult the DUS.

provenance.quote: The major in Jewish Studies requires thirteen term courses, including three courses selected from a set of core requirements, a language or literature requirement, three courses selected from each of two areas of focus, and the senior requirement.

Each student must elect at least three from the following: (1) a course in Hebrew Bible, such as JDST 1000; (2) a course in rabbinic literature or ancient Judaism, such as JDST 3035; (3) JDST 2000; (4) JDST 2001; (5) a course in Jewish thought, such as JDST 3681 or JDST 3693; (6) a survey course in Hebrew and Jewish literature.
Students must complete either HEBR 1100 and 1200 or two courses in Hebrew literature in translation.
Students must select two of the following focus areas... In each of the two areas of focus, students choose three courses in consultation with the DUS.
No more than one course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the major requirements.
Courses taken at another institution or during an approved summer or term-time study abroad program may count toward the major requirements with DUS approval.
Students are required either to complete a two-term senior essay in JDST 4491 and JDST 4492... or to complete a one-term senior essay in JDST 4491 or JDST 4492... and an additional seminar.

constraints.description: Other such courses require DUS approval; written approval is advised.

senior_requirement.description: During the senior year, complete any Math course numbered MATH 4800–4890, or with DUS consent complete MATH 4750 senior essay (written and oral report).

Senior Essay.description: Senior essay in Mathematics with consent of the DUS; includes written and oral report.

policies.credit_d_fail_note: No course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the requirements of the major.

outside_credit.notes: Courses taken after matriculation at Yale or during approved study abroad may count toward the major requirements with DUS approval.

other_policies.Course counting (B.A.): B.A.—10 term courses in Mathematics numbered 2250 or higher (including the senior requirement); MATH 4700 excluded.
other_policies.Course counting (B.S.): B.S.—12 term courses in Mathematics numbered 2250 or higher (including the senior requirement); MATH 4700 excluded.
other_policies.Specific course requirements: MATH 3500; at least one of MATH 3050 or MATH 3100.
other_policies.Substitutions: With prior written DUS permission, a higher-level course in the same area may substitute (typically MATH 3700 for algebra, MATH 3200 for real analysis, MATH 3150 for complex analysis).
other_policies.Up to two outside math-intensive courses: With DUS approval, up to two math-intensive courses from other departments may be counted among the ten courses required for the Mathematics major.
other_policies.Graduate courses counting: Graduate courses numbered 5000–5999 may be counted toward the requirements of the major; courses 6000 and above cannot be counted toward undergraduate major requirements.
other_policies.Intensive major: Intensive majors must include MATH 3050, MATH 3100, and MATH 3500, and at least two graduate Math courses level 5000+ or equivalent independent study among the required courses.
other_policies.Distinction in the Major: To be eligible, a student must have completed MATH 3050, MATH 3100, and MATH 3500.
other_policies.Requirement version policy: Students are held to the requirements in place when they declared; with DUS approval, updated requirements may be fulfilled by students who declared earlier.

provenance.quote: Prerequisite for both the B.A and B.S. degree programs is single variable calculus, through the level of MATH 1150 or equivalent.
Introductory sequence requirement: Linear algebra with proofs (MATH 2250 or 2260), Real analysis (MATH 2550 or 2560), and Vector analysis or Multivariable calculus (MATH 3020 or 1200).
B.A. degree program consists of ten term courses in Mathematics numbered 2250 or higher (including the senior requirement), but excluding MATH 4700.

B.S. degree program consists of twelve term courses and follows the same requirements as for the B.A. degree, with the addition of at least two advanced term courses in the physical sciences (ASTR 4180, ASTR 4300, CHEM 3330, 4700, PHYS 4010 or 4100, PHYS 4020 or 4300, PHYS 4400, PHYS 4410, PHYS 4500).
Specific courses required: MATH 3500 (algebra), and at least one of MATH 3050 (real analysis) or MATH 3100 (complex analysis).
Distribution of courses: at least three courses that carry the 'math distribution' attribute (YC MATH Distribution).
Senior Requirement: During the senior year, take any Math course numbered MATH 4800 through MATH 4890, or MATH 4750 senior essay with consent of the DUS.

senior_requirement.description: Complete a designated senior seminar in Philosophy or a Mathematics seminar (MATH 4800–4890). If a Philosophy seminar is used, additional work (e.g., substantial presentation and/or draft series before the final paper) is required in agreement with the instructor.

Standard.description: Take a Mathematics senior seminar (any course numbered MATH 4800–4890) or a designated Philosophy seminar approved for the combined major.

policies.credit_d_fail_note: No more than one course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the major (including the prerequisite), with permission of the DUSs.

outside_credit.notes: Courses taken after matriculation at Yale at another institution or during approved summer or term-time study abroad may count toward the major with DUS approval.

other_policies.philosophy_course_eligibility: All philosophy courses are eligible for credit toward the major except PHIL 1115.
other_policies.timing_requirement: MATH 2700 and PHIL 2267 must be taken before the end of the junior year; strongly recommended earlier.
other_policies.math_listing_policy: A course must be listed with a MATH number to count toward the mathematics requirements; substitutions from other departments are not permitted.
other_policies.graduate_math_courses: Graduate MATH courses 5000–5999 may be counted as electives; graduate MATH courses 6000 or above may not be counted.
other_policies.letter_grade_requirements: The following must be taken for letter grades: MATH 2700, PHIL 2267, PHIL 4427; required MATH courses level 2220 or higher; the advanced PHIL course with a logical component; and the senior seminar.
other_policies.senior_seminar_additional_work: If a designated Philosophy seminar is used to fulfill the senior requirement, additional work (such as a substantial presentation and/or draft series) must be completed in consultation with the instructor.
other_policies.prerequisite_substitution: With prior written permission from the Mathematics DUS, students who completed multivariable calculus in high school may substitute a higher-level mathematics course in the same area for MATH 1200.

provenance.quote: The prerequisite for the major is MATH 1200.
The major requires twelve term courses including the prerequisite and the senior seminar.
Of the remaining courses, at least four must be in mathematics level 2220–4690, and five must be in philosophy. The remaining course may be either a mathematics or philosophy course.
Required courses include Set Theory (MATH 2700), Mathematical Logic (PHIL 2267), Computability and Logic (PHIL 4427).
All philosophy courses are eligible for credit toward the major, except First-Order Logic (PHIL 1115).
Set Theory (MATH 2700) and Mathematical Logic (PHIL 2267) must be taken before the end of the junior year; it is strongly recommended that they be taken earlier.
A course must be listed with a MATH number to count toward the mathematics requirements—substitutions from other departments are not permitted.
Graduate mathematics courses level 5000–5999 may be counted as electives; graduate mathematics courses level 6000 or above may not be counted.
The mathematics seminars, numbered MATH 4800 through 4890, fulfill the senior requirement. For philosophy seminars that fulfill the senior requirement, consult the DUS in Philosophy.
No more than one course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the requirements of the major (including the prerequisite), with permission of the DUSs.
Outside credit may count toward the major requirements with DUS approval.

constraints.description: Chosen in consultation with the DUS; only one of MENG 4991 or MENG 4992 may count toward the major.

senior_requirement.description: Students satisfy the senior project requirement by completing MENG 4154; MENG 4991 or MENG 4992; or another upper-level design course taken during the senior year and chosen in consultation with the DUS.

Standard.description: One of the listed courses or another upper-level design course approved by the DUS.

repeat_for_credit_limits.quote_justification: Only one Special Projects Course (MENG 4991 or MENG 4992) may be counted toward the requirements of the major.

policies.credit_d_fail_note: No course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the requirements of the major, including prerequisites.

outside_credit.notes: Courses taken at another institution or during an approved summer or term-time study abroad program may count toward the major requirements with DUS approval.

other_policies.advising: Students should consult with the DUS at the beginning of their sophomore year. Prospective majors in both B.S. programs are advised to complete introductory physics and mathematics through calculus by the end of the first year.
other_policies.special_projects_limit: Only one Special Projects Course (MENG 4991 or MENG 4992) may be counted toward the requirements of the major.

provenance.quote: The major requires twelve approved course credits in engineering (with only one course from MENG 4991 or MENG 4992), beyond the prerequisites and including the senior project.
Prerequisites: MATH 1120, MATH 1150, and ENAS 1510; PHYS 1800, PHYS 1810, or PHYS 2000, PHYS 2010; one lab from PHYS 1650L or PHYS 2050L, and one from PHYS 1660L, PHYS 2060L, or MENG 2616L.
Senior requirement: MENG 4154; MENG 4991 or MENG 4992; or another upper-level design course taken during the senior year and chosen in consultation with the DUS.
Students should consult with the DUS at the beginning of their sophomore year.

constraints.description: Chosen in consultation with the DUS; only one of MENG 4991 or MENG 4992 may count among the technical electives.

senior_requirement.description: Students satisfy the senior requirement by taking MENG 4137L (full-credit) and MENG 4138L (half-credit) in the senior year.

Standard.description: Senior design/project laboratory sequence taken in senior year.

policies.credit_d_fail_note: No course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the requirements of the major, including prerequisites.

outside_credit.notes: Courses taken at another institution or during an approved summer or term-time study abroad program may count toward the major requirements with DUS approval.

other_policies.substitutions_policy: Departures from the prescribed curriculum possible with DUS approval.
other_policies.special_projects_limit: Only one of MENG 4991 or MENG 4992 may be counted among the three technical electives.
other_policies.abet_accreditation: Accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET, Inc.
other_policies.advising: Prospective majors in both B.S. programs are advised to complete introductory physics and mathematics through calculus by the end of the first year.
other_policies.chemistry_waiver: The introductory chemistry lecture may be waived for a Chemistry AP score of 4 or 5 or an IB Higher level or Standard level score of 6 or 7.

provenance.quote: B.S. degree program in Mechanical Engineering ... is accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET, Inc.
The prerequisites in mathematics are MATH 1120, MATH 1150, and ENAS 1510, or the equivalent.
PHYS 1800, PHYS 1810, or PHYS 2000, PHYS 2010; one laboratory from PHYS 1650L or PHYS 2050L, and one from PHYS 1660L or PHYS 2060L.
One introductory lecture course in chemistry, numbered CHEM 1610 or higher.
Requires twenty courses for 19.5 credits beyond the prerequisites.
3 technical electives ... only one course from MENG 4991 or MENG 4992 may be counted.
Senior requirement: MENG 4137L (full-credit) and MENG 4138L (half-credit) in the senior year.

constraints.description: Chosen in consultation with the DUS; only one of MENG 4991 or MENG 4992 may count toward the major.

senior_requirement.description: Students satisfy the senior project requirement by completing MENG 4991 or MENG 4992; or another upper-level design course taken during their senior year and chosen in consultation with the DUS.

Standard.description: One of the listed courses or another upper-level design course approved by the DUS.

policies.credit_d_fail_note: No course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the requirements of the major, including prerequisites.

outside_credit.notes: Courses taken at another institution or during an approved summer or term-time study abroad program may count toward the major requirements with DUS approval.

other_policies.special_projects_limit: Only one Special Projects Course (MENG 4991 or MENG 4992) may be counted toward the requirements of the major.
other_policies.advising: Students should consult with the DUS at the beginning of their sophomore year.

provenance.quote: B.A. prerequisites: MATH 1120 and MATH 1150; physics at least to the level of PHYS 1700, PHYS 1710.
Program requires eight approved course credits in engineering (with only one course from MENG 4991 or MENG 4992), beyond the prerequisites, including the senior project.
Senior requirement: MENG 4991 or MENG 4992; or another upper-level design course chosen in consultation with the DUS.

distributions.category: Introductory modern Middle East survey courses

constraints.attribute: Introductory-level survey courses focusing on the modern period of the Middle East
Courses focusing on culture, thought, history, religion, politics, and society of the region
constraints.description: Up to two language courses below L5 in a Modern Middle East language may count toward the distributional requirement with approval of the director of undergraduate studies.

sub_requirements.label: Courses from different Middle Eastern regions or countries

constraints.description: Select courses representing at least two distinct regions or countries within the Middle East.

sub_requirements.label: Courses from two different departments or programs

constraints.description: Courses must be drawn from at least two distinct departments or programs.

sub_requirements.label: Courses focusing substantially on the period before 1750

constraints.attribute: Focus substantially on the period before 1750

senior_requirement.description: A one- or two-term senior essay involving use of materials in one or more modern Middle Eastern languages; students select a faculty adviser with competence in the appropriate language; prospectus and outline signed by the adviser due by the end of the fourth week of classes in either term of the senior year; essays are graded by the adviser and a second reader. Alternatively, majors may take an additional seminar and write an essay in that course to fulfill the senior requirement.

policies.credit_d_fail_note: No course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the requirements of the major.

outside_credit.notes: Courses taken at another institution or during an approved summer or term-time study abroad program may count toward the major requirements with DUS approval.

other_policies.course_of_study_dus_approval: The proposed course of study requires DUS approval

provenance.quote: There are no prerequisites.
Twelve term courses are required for the major, including one course at the L5 level in a Middle Eastern language and two survey courses on the modern period, taken at the introductory level.
Beyond those requirements, students take eight distribution courses focusing on any aspect of the culture, thought, history, religion, politics, and society of the region.

They must include, at a minimum, two courses from different regions or countries within the Middle East, two courses from different departments or programs, two courses that focus substantially on the period before 1750, and two advanced seminars.
Up to two language courses below L5 in a Modern Middle East language may count toward the distributional requirement with the approval of the director of undergraduate studies (DUS).
No course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the requirements of the major.
Courses taken at another institution or during an approved summer or term-time study abroad program may count toward the major requirements with DUS approval.
Students in the major undertake a one- or two-term senior essay ... See the course descriptions of the senior essay courses (MMES 4491, 4492, 4493) for further information.

policies.credit_d_fail_note: No course taken Credit/D/Fail may be counted toward the program in Naval Science.

other_policies.enrollment_pattern: Students in the NROTC program enroll in one Naval Science course per term.
other_policies.laboratory_requirement: All NROTC students must also enroll in the Naval Science Laboratory each term.
other_policies.graduation_credit_courses: Most Naval Science courses count for enrollment credit only; NAVY 2110 and NAVY 4120 do count toward graduation credit.
other_policies.option_requirements_navy: Navy-option students must complete two terms of calculus by the sophomore year, two terms of calculus-based physics with lab by the junior year, two terms of English or equivalent writing, one term of history or national security policy, and one term of world culture or regional studies.
other_policies.option_requirements_marine: Marine-option students must complete two term courses in English or equivalent writing and one term course in history or national security policy.
other_policies.application_scholarship: Applicants use the online application for the National Scholarship Program; recipients are appointed midshipmen and receive tuition, fees, textbook stipend, subsistence allowance, uniforms or compensation in lieu, for up to four years.
other_policies.commission_commitment_scholarship: Upon conferral of a degree, scholarship graduates are commissioned for a minimum of five years of active duty service.
other_policies.application_college_program: First- or second-year students may apply to the College Program and compete for two- or three-year scholarships; if selected, they receive the same benefits for the remaining undergraduate studies.
other_policies.commission_commitment_college_program: College Program graduates are commissioned for a minimum of three years of active duty service.

provenance.quote: Students in the NROTC program enroll in one Naval Science course per term.

Most Naval Science courses count for enrollment credit only; they do not count toward the thirty-six course credits required for the Yale bachelor's degree. NAVY 2110 and NAVY 4120 do count toward graduation credit.
All NROTC students must also enroll in the Naval Science Laboratory each term.
Navy-option students must complete eight core curriculum courses...
Marine-option students must complete three core curriculum courses...

senior_requirement.description: Independent research project advised by faculty, culminating in an essay (one-semester ~25–35 pages; year-long ~45–55 pages).

policies.credit_d_fail_note: No more than one course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the major.

outside_credit.notes: A maximum of two outside credits (other institution or approved study abroad) may count toward the major with DUS approval.

other_policies.concentration_choice: Students choose either the Depth or Breadth concentration.
other_policies.outside_department_courses_limit: No more than two courses from outside the department may count toward the major.
other_policies.placement_test: Students with experience in a modern language must take a placement test at the beginning of the fall term.
other_policies.attributes_reference: See attributes indicating courses approved for Near Eastern Languages and Civilizations major requirements.
other_policies.dus_consultation_required: Students design a coherent program of study in consultation with the DUS.
other_policies.outside_courses_require_dus_approval: Courses taken outside Yale or outside the department may count toward the major only with DUS approval.

provenance.quote: The major requires twelve term courses, including the senior requirement.
Students develop coherent programs of study in one of two concentrations.
Depth: 6 term courses in one or two Near Eastern languages; one NELC Foundations course; four NELC electives; and the senior project.
Breadth: four term courses in Near Eastern languages; two NELC Foundations courses; five NELC electives, including one ancient, one medieval, and one modern; and the senior project.
Senior requirement NELC 4920 and/or NELC 4930.
No more than one course taken Cr/D/Fail can be applied toward the requirements of the major.
A maximum of two outside credits is allowed.
No more than two courses taken from outside the department can be counted toward fulfilling the major.

constraints.description: B.A. students typically complete two core courses. B.S. students typically complete three core courses.

Biological sciences lab may be selected from MCDB, MB&B, BENG, or with DUS permission from Anthropology or E&EB. If laboratories are used as an elective they cannot also fulfill the laboratory requirement. B.S. students typically complete two MCDB laboratories. Two laboratory courses, either MCDB 3420L and 3430L or MCDB 3440L and 3450L, can be paired for a single elective credit; if used as an elective, these laboratories cannot also fulfill the laboratory requirement.

senior_requirement.description: All students must complete a senior requirement during the senior year. B.A. students may submit a 15–20 page senior essay evaluating current research (no course credit) or complete one term of individual research. B.S. students usually complete a yearlong research sequence; B.S. intensive students complete an intensive yearlong research sequence (each term worth two credits). Senior research courses do not satisfy other major requirements.

B.A. Research.description: One term of individual research in the senior year.

B.S. Research.description: Two consecutive terms of independent research in the senior year.

B.S. Intensive Research.description: Intensive yearlong senior research; each course carries two credits.

policies.credit_d_fail_note: No course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the requirements of the major, including prerequisites.

outside_credit.notes: Courses taken at another institution or during approved study abroad may count toward the major requirements with DUS approval.

other_policies.independent_research_pre_senior: MCDB 4740 is Pass/Fail, counts toward degree total, and does not substitute for any MCDB major requirement or lab requirement.
other_policies.independent_research_senior: MCDB 4750, 4850, 4860, 4950, and 4960 exist primarily to fulfill the senior requirement and do not satisfy other requirements for the major; no independent research course satisfies a lab requirement.
other_policies.double_major_restriction: The MCDB major should not be taken as one of two majors with Molecular Biophysics and Biochemistry, Ecology and Evolutionary Biology, or Neuroscience.
other_policies.placement_biology: Students may place out of one or more BIOL 1010–1040 modules by placement exam; students who do not complete BIOL 1010–1040 take one or two advanced lecture or seminar courses at MCDB 2000 level or above to complete the biology prerequisite, with DUS approval.
other_policies.placement_chemistry: Placement in chemistry is arranged by the Department of Chemistry; students are encouraged to take general and organic chemistry in the first/sophomore years as required chemistry is prerequisite to several MCDB courses.
other_policies.acceleration_credit: Acceleration credit awarded in chemistry, mathematics, or physics, or completion of advanced courses in those subjects, is accepted in place of corresponding prerequisites; B.A. students who satisfy prerequisites with advanced placement must still complete three term courses in chemistry and physics at Yale, including at least one from each department.
other_policies.concentrations_policy: Optional concentrations in Biotechnology, Neurobiology, and Quantitative Biology require one specific course (MCDB 3700, MCDB 3200, or MCDB 3310) and one approved elective; concentration courses cannot double count toward multiple concentrations or other major requirements; no substitutions provided.

provenance.quote: B.A.—2 core courses from MCDB 2000, 2020, 2050, 2100, 2900, 3000 (or MB&B 3000); 2 electives numbered MCDB 2500 or above; 1 elective numbered MCDB 3500 or above; 1 biology lab.
B.S.—3 core courses from MCDB 2000, 2020, 2050, 2100, 2900, 3000 (or MB&B 3000); 2 electives numbered MCDB 2500 or above; 1 elective numbered MCDB 3500 or above; 2 MCDB labs.
All majors must also complete a course in mathematics numbered MATH 1150 or higher or a statistics course (S&DS 1000, 1080, 1090, 2380).

Two laboratory courses, either MCDB 3420L and 3430L or MCDB 3440L and 3450L, can be paired for a single elective credit. If used as an elective, these laboratories cannot also fulfill the laboratory requirement.
B.A. senior requirement: senior essay of 15–20 pages or one term of individual research (MCDB 4750).
B.S. senior requirement: yearlong research course, MCDB 4850, 4860.
B.S. intensive major: MCDB 4950, 4960 for four course credits.
No course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the requirements of the major, including prerequisites.
Outside credit may count toward the major requirements with DUS approval.
The MCDB major should not be taken as one of two majors with Molecular Biophysics and Biochemistry, Ecology and Evolutionary Biology, or Neuroscience.
Students who do not complete the introductory BIOL sequence take one or two advanced lecture or seminar courses (MCDB 2000 level or above) to complete the biology prerequisite.

Qualified students ... may offer up to four terms of instruction in performance for academic credit ... up to three may be applied to the major in Music.

senior_requirement.description: All seniors must complete a senior requirement undertaken during the senior year. B.S.: two course credits of empirical research (NSCI 4900 and NSCI 4910) with written assignments, capstone seminar participation, and a spring poster presentation. B.A.: either two course credits in nonempirical research (NSCI 4800 and NSCI 4810) or one nonempirical (NSCI 4800 or 4810) plus one empirical (NSCI 4900 or 4910), with written assignments and a spring poster presentation.

B.S. Empirical Research.description: Two-term empirical research sequence; includes research plan, grant proposal, final report, capstone seminar, and spring poster session.

B.A. Nonempirical Research.description: Two-term nonempirical research (e.g., theory development or meta-analysis with novel contributions); includes research plan, literature review/draft, and final theoretical paper.

B.A. Mixed (4800 + 4900).description: One term nonempirical plus one term empirical research.

B.A. Mixed (4810 + 4900).description: One term nonempirical plus one term empirical research.

B.A. Mixed (4800 + 4910).description: One term nonempirical plus one term empirical research.

B.A. Mixed (4810 + 4910).description: One term nonempirical plus one term empirical research.

other_policies.Double major restriction: Due to overlap in requirements, Neuroscience should not be combined with a second major in Molecular, Cellular and Developmental Biology or Psychology.

other_policies.Senior research registration: To register for NSCI 4900 and 4910 or NSCI 4800 and 4810, students must submit a form and a research plan with bibliography, approved by the faculty adviser and a DUS, by the end of the first week of classes.
other_policies.Early foundation courses recommended: Students are encouraged to take NSCI 1600 (Human Brain) and NSCI 3200 (Neurobiology) as early as possible.
other_policies.Program website: More detailed guidelines, forms, deadlines, and approved course lists are available on the Neuroscience program website.
other_policies.Other Allied Core limit: No more than 2 courses may be counted from the Other Allied Core.

provenance.quote: A minimum of 18.5 credits is required, including the prerequisites (5 courses for 3 credits), 15 lecture or seminar courses (which include the senior requirement), and one laboratory.

One Neuroscience lab chosen from NSCI 2280L, 2290L, 2400, NSCI 2580, 2600, 2700, 3210L; PSYC 2538.
Minimum of 2 Systems/Circuits/Behavior Core, 2 Molecular/Cellular/Biological Core, 1 Quantitative Core, 1 Computational Core, 1 Basic Allied Core; no more than 2 Other Allied Core.
The foundational biology courses required of all Neuroscience majors are BIOL 1010, 1020, 1030, and 1040.
All majors must also complete one of the following: PSYC 2100, S&DS 1030, 1050, 2300, 2380.

B.A. degree program requires two course credits in nonempirical research, NSCI 4800 and 4810; or one nonempirical (NSCI 4800 or 4810) and one empirical (NSCI 4900 or 4910).
Independent research courses before senior year (NSCI 4700, 4710) are graded Pass/Fail and do not substitute for any NSCI major requirement; do not satisfy the lab requirement.
Neuroscience major should not be combined with a second major in MCDB or Psychology.

The core Biophysics requirements are two semesters of physics (PHYS 1700 and 1710 or higher) and one semester of biophysical chemistry (MB&B 2750 or CHEM 3320).

senior_requirement.description: Normally satisfied by completing a third philosophy seminar with additional work (e.g., extra readings, an early full draft revised later, and meetings with the instructor). Students should inform the instructor at the start of term. In special cases, the requirement may be met through a one-term or two-term independent project, by petition and with DUS approval.

Two-term Independent Project.description: Two-term independent study supervised by an instructor; petition required and approval not guaranteed.

outside_credit.notes: Courses taken at another institution or during approved study abroad may count toward the major with DUS approval. With DUS approval, normally no more than two courses from other departments may count toward the major; courses taken in other departments and applied to the major will not normally count toward a group requirement; petitions are possible but disfavored.

other_policies.Outside courses limit: With DUS approval, normally no more than two courses from other departments may count toward the major.

other_policies.Psychology concentration summary: Concentration requires 7 philosophy courses (including 2 history, a logic course, 2 seminars—one may be in PSYC with DUS approval—and at least 2 intermediate/advanced intersection courses, one a PHIL seminar, with DUS approval) and 5 psychology courses including PSYC 1100; senior requirement as in the standard major.

provenance.quote: The standard major requires twelve term courses (including the prerequisites and the senior requirement).
Majors are required to take PHIL 1125 and PHIL 1126 (DRST 0003 and DRST 0004 can substitute).
Majors must also complete two courses in metaphysics and epistemology, two courses in ethics and value theory, and a course in logic (such as PHIL 1115).
Majors must also take two advanced seminars at the 3000+ level.
With approval from the DUS, courses offered by other departments may be counted toward the major requirements, though no more than two such courses will normally be allowed.
Courses count toward the group under which they are listed in YCS; no one course can be counted toward two group requirements.

The senior requirement is normally satisfied by completing a third philosophy seminar... In special cases, students may meet the senior requirement through either a one-term or a two-term independent project (PHIL 4490, PHIL 4491).
Credit/D/Fail: At most one class taken Credit/D/Fail can count toward the requirements of the major; such courses cannot fulfill distribution, seminar, or senior requirements.

The B.S./M.S. program follows the requirements of the B.S. Degree program with the following additions.

For the core Biophysics requirement: one additional 3000+ course in thermodynamics, statistical mech, quantum and/or spectroscopy (CHEM 3320 is recommended). PHYS 1800 and 1810 in place of PHYS 1700 and 1710.
The Practical Skills requirement is replaced by one semester of MB&B 4700 or MB&B 4710 which must be completed by the end of the fifth semester.

The senior requirement for B.S./M.S. is completion of MB&B 5700 and 5701 taken during senior year.

provenance.quote: Prerequisites: mathematics through calculus at the level of MATH 1200; any introductory physics lecture sequence PHYS 1700, 1710 or higher; PHYS 1650L and 1660L, or PHYS 2050L.
Beyond the prerequisites, students take fifteen courses for fourteen and a half course credits, including the senior requirement.

Six courses in Philosophy or in History of Science, Medicine, and Public Health are required, including PHIL 1125 and PHIL 1126, one course in logic above the introductory level, and a philosophy seminar selected with the approval of the DUSs.

other_policies.Admissions_application_platform: Applications are submitted through SOPHAS Express.
other_policies.Admissions_application_requirements: Application includes transcripts, SAT scores, two letters of recommendation (at least one from an instructor of a Yale course), and a personal statement.
other_policies.Recommended_preparation: Two terms each of college-level mathematics, science, and social science are recommended; some courses may be completed after applying.
other_policies.Admissions_contact: Questions about admissions should be directed to Mary Keefe (mary.keefe@yale.edu).
other_policies.Further_information: Further information about the program may be viewed on the YSPH website.

provenance.quote: The B.A.–B.S./M.P.H. degree program ... offers Yale College students ... an M.P.H. degree ... in a five-year joint program.
Four of the thirty-six course credits required for the bachelor’s degree are typically taken at YSPH.
No more than four course credits earned in the professional schools may be applied toward the bachelor’s degree.
Two Yale College courses selected from an approved list may be counted as electives toward the M.P.H. degree requirements.
Students ... typically take the following courses ... PUBH 505 ... PUBH 507 ... PUBH 508 ... PUBH 510 ... PUBH 513.
During the summer between the fourth and fifth years, students complete a public health internship.
During the fifth year, students are in full-time residence at the School of Public Health to complete their remaining coursework and master’s thesis.
Students apply to the B.A.–B.S./M.P.H. program in the fall term of the junior year ... SOPHAS Express ... transcripts, SAT scores, two letters ... personal statement.
Two terms each of college-level mathematics, science, and social science courses are recommended.

distributions.category: South Asian Studies courses numbered 2000 or above

constraints.subject: SAST
constraints.others_with_approval_of: With DUS approval, one relevant course from another department may count; up to three study abroad credits may count.

senior_requirement.description: Complete a senior essay in a seminar or a one-credit, one-term senior essay in consultation with a faculty advisor. DUS approval of plans early in the senior year is required. The essay should be a substantial paper of 8,000–10,000 words; use of primary materials in regional languages is encouraged.

Standard.description: Either write a senior essay as part of a seminar or enroll in SAST 4910 for a one-term senior essay (fall or spring of senior year).

policies.credit_d_fail_note: No more than one course taken Credit/D/Fail may count toward the major requirements.

outside_credit.notes: Courses taken at another institution or during approved study abroad may count toward the major requirements with DUS approval. Up to three course credits from approved study abroad programs may be applied toward the major with DUS permission.

other_policies.second_major_only: South Asian Studies can be taken only as a second major.
other_policies.language_requirement: One South Asian language must be studied at the advanced (L5) level; Yale offers L5 in Hindi and Sanskrit. Substitution of another appropriate language (e.g., Persian or Arabic) may be approved by the DUS; proficiency in other South Asian languages may be demonstrated through testing.
other_policies.language_exam_additional_course: Students who fulfill the L5 language requirement via exam must take an additional term course (total eight term courses).
other_policies.advising: The proposed course of study must be approved each term by the DUS; students should identify an adviser from South Asian Studies faculty early.
other_policies.graduate_courses: Graduate courses in South Asian Studies are open to qualified undergraduates with permission of the instructor and the director of graduate studies.
other_policies.two_majors_permission: Permission to complete two majors must be secured from the Committee on Honors and Academic Standing; applications must be submitted prior to the final term.
other_policies.senior_req_version_policy: Students are held to the senior requirements in place when they declared the major; updated 2024–2025 requirements may be fulfilled with DUS approval.
other_policies.outside_credit_policy: Courses taken at another institution or during approved study abroad may count toward the major requirements with DUS approval.
other_policies.study_abroad_limit: Up to three course credits from approved study abroad programs may be applied toward the major with DUS permission.

provenance.quote: South Asian Studies can be taken only as a second major.
must complete seven term courses in South Asian Studies numbered 2000 or above.
At least two of the seven courses must address premodern South Asia, and at least two should be seminars.
Students may petition the director of undergraduate studies (DUS) to include one relevant course from another department; approval may require additional coursework on South Asian topics.
Up to three course credits from approved study abroad programs may be applied toward the requirements of the major, with permission of the DUS.
One South Asian language must be studied at the advanced level (L5).
Students who fulfill the major requirement through the successful completion of an L5 language exam must take an additional term course for a total of eight term courses.
The senior requirement may be fulfilled by the completion of a seminar that culminates in a senior essay. Alternatively, ... a one-credit, one-term senior essay ... in SAST 4910.
The senior essay can be written in either the fall or spring of the student's senior year.
The DUS must approve senior requirement plans early in the student’s senior year.
Credit/D/Fail—No more than one course taken Credit/D/Fail may count toward the requirements of the major.

senior_requirement.description: All majors complete a senior requirement. Non-intensive majors complete one additional Sociology seminar (SOCY 3000–3999) and a one-term senior essay (SOCY 4100) in the senior year. Intensive majors complete a yearlong research colloquium and senior essay across SOCY 4200, 4201 in the senior year; intensive majors are eligible for Distinction in the Major if grade standards are met and the senior essay is submitted.

Non-Intensive.description: One additional SOCY 3000–3999 seminar plus a one-credit senior essay written in SOCY 4100 during senior year; non-intensive majors are not eligible for Distinction in the Major.

Intensive.description: Two-term senior colloquium and essay (SOCY 4200, 4201) with a yearlong original research project; eligible for Distinction in the Major if grade standards are met and the senior essay is submitted.

policies.credit_d_fail_note: No more than two courses taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the requirements of the major.

outside_credit.notes: Courses taken at another institution or during an approved summer or term-time study abroad program may count toward the major requirements with DUS approval.

other_policies.intro_course_limit: At least one introductory Sociology course is required; no more than two introductory Sociology courses may count toward the total.
other_policies.credit_d_fail_limit: No more than two courses taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the requirements of the major.
other_policies.outside_credit_policy: Courses taken at another institution or during an approved summer or term-time study abroad program may count toward the major requirements with DUS approval.
other_policies.research_design_timing: SOCY 2100 is usually completed in the spring of the junior year.
other_policies.concentrations_offered: Standard; Economy and Society; Health and Society; Data and Society; Inequality, Race, and Society; Student-Designed.
other_policies.standard_major_theory_requirement: Standard major requires SOCY 2001 and SOCY 2002.
other_policies.student_designed_theory_requirement: Student-Designed concentration requires SOCY 2001 and SOCY 2002.
other_policies.economy_society_requirements: Requires SOCY 2001 or SOCY 2002; SOCY 2100; one intermediate or advanced microeconomics course (e.g., ECON 2121 or ECON 2125); one social science methodology course; two intermediate or advanced courses on inequality or economic sociology; up to four outside courses relevant to the concentration with DUS approval.
other_policies.health_society_requirements: Requires SOCY 1600 or SOCY 1601 (gateway); SOCY 2001 or SOCY 2002; SOCY 2100; one social science methodology course; two intermediate or advanced Sociology courses relevant to the concentration; up to five outside courses with DUS approval (recommended to include BIOL 1010–1040, MATH 1120 or higher, ECON 2170).
other_policies.data_society_requirements: Requires SOCY 2001 or SOCY 2002; SOCY 2100; one introductory statistics course (e.g., S&DS 1000, 1100, 3630, or GLBL 2121); one intermediate or advanced statistics course (e.g., SOCY 5610 or SOCY 5620); two additional methods courses; one semester of independent study as a research assistant; up to four outside courses with DUS approval.
other_policies.inequality_race_society_requirements: Requires SOCY 1700 (gateway); SOCY 2001 or SOCY 2002; SOCY 2100; one social science methodology course; five courses related to race or inequality (up to two may be from outside the department with DUS approval).
other_policies.student_designed_requirements: Requires 13 term courses including senior requirement; up to four outside courses forming a coherent unit with DUS approval; SOCY 2001 and SOCY 2002; SOCY 2100; one social science methodology course; one intermediate or advanced Sociology seminar; senior requirement must integrate sociology with the other subject.
other_policies.outside_dept_course_limits: Economy & Society and Data & Society and Student-Designed: up to 4 outside courses with DUS approval; Health & Society: up to 5 outside courses with DUS approval; Inequality, Race, and Society: up to 2 outside courses with DUS approval.
other_policies.advising: Students should meet with the DUS no later than the beginning of the junior year to elect a program of study; qualified students may petition to enroll in graduate courses with permission.
other_policies.intensive_major_admission: Candidates should indicate interest to the DUS by registration period in the spring for the fall term of the senior year.
other_policies.study_abroad_guidance: Students planning to study abroad in junior year are strongly encouraged to begin meeting specific requirements in sophomore year and discuss plans with the DUS.

provenance.quote: Prerequisite: None.
Number of courses: 13 term courses (incl senior req) for standard major and all concentrations.
Standard major—at least 1, but no more than 2 intro courses, SOCY 2001, 2002, 2100, and a course in sociological methods.

Economy & Society—SOCY 2001 or 2002, SOCY 2100, microeconomics course, sociological methods course, two intermediate/advanced courses on inequality or economic sociology; up to four outside courses with DUS approval.
Health & Society—SOCY 1600 or 1601, SOCY 2001 or 2002, SOCY 2100, methods course, two intermediate or advanced Sociology courses; up to five outside courses with DUS approval.
Data and Society—SOCY 2001 or 2002, SOCY 2100, intro stats, intermediate/advanced stats, two additional methods courses, one independent study; up to four outside courses with DUS approval.
Inequality, Race, and Society—SOCY 1700, SOCY 2001 or 2002, SOCY 2100, methods course, five courses related to race or inequality; up to two outside courses with DUS approval.
Senior requirement (non-intensive): one additional SOCY 3000–3999 seminar and one-term senior essay (SOCY 4100) in senior year.
Senior requirement (intensive): SOCY 4200, 4201; eligible for Distinction in the Major if standards met and senior essay submitted.
Credit/D/Fail courses: No more than two may be applied toward the major.

constraints.subject: SPAN
constraints.description: The three elective courses must be numbered SPAN 2000 or higher, or be a first-year seminar taught in Spanish.

senior_requirement.description: An essay or its equivalent in another medium completed in SPAN 4900 under the direction of a faculty adviser; taken in spring of the senior year, or in fall for December graduates.

policies.credit_d_fail_note: No course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the requirements of the major.

outside_credit.notes: Courses taken at another institution or during an approved summer or term-time study abroad program may count toward the major requirements with DUS approval.

other_policies.Electives: The three elective courses must be numbered SPAN 2000 or higher, or be a first-year seminar taught in Spanish.

other_policies.Graduate courses: Juniors and seniors may enroll in graduate courses in Spanish with permission of the instructor and the director of graduate studies.
other_policies.Two majors: Students electing Spanish as one of two majors should consult the DUS about a specialized course of study.
other_policies.Study abroad: Students should consult the DUS before going abroad to count courses; Yale Summer Session offers programs in Spain and Ecuador.

provenance.quote: Prerequisite to the major is SPAN 1400, SPAN 1450, SPAN 1500, or the equivalent.
Beyond the prerequisite, ten term courses are required. SPAN 2200 is a required introductory course.
Additionally, two courses numbered SPAN 2200–2999 are required, as are three courses numbered SPAN 3000 or higher.
SPAN 4900, The Senior Project, is one of the ten required courses.
The remaining three elective courses must be numbered SPAN 2000 or higher, or be a first-year seminar taught in Spanish.
A maximum of one course taught in a language other than Spanish may also count toward the major requirements, with the approval of the DUS.
No course taken Credit/D/Fail may be applied toward the requirements of the major.
Courses taken at another institution or during an approved summer or term-time study abroad program may count toward the major requirements with DUS approval.
Seniors complete the senior requirement ... in SPAN 4900 in the spring of their senior year ... December complete ... in the fall.
Students in the intensive major ... take two additional courses numbered SPAN 3000 or higher, totaling 12 term courses.

program_name: Certificate of Advanced Language Study in Indonesian

policies.credit_d_fail_note: No courses taken Credit/D/Fail may be counted toward the requirements of the certificate.

outside_credit.notes: Up to two credits earned during study abroad and taught in the target language may count; approved outside courses must appear on the Yale transcript.

other_policies.grade_requirement: All courses must be taken for a letter grade, and students must achieve a grade of B or above.
other_policies.advisor_approved_course_limit: With adviser approval, up to one advanced-level course conducted in the target language—such as INDN 4700 or INDN 4710 (Pass/Fail) or INDN 5700 (graduate seminar)—may count toward certification.
other_policies.declaration_deadline: Students must declare on Yale Hub by January 15 or September 15 in their last semester.
other_policies.contact: For more information, email the Southeast Asia Language Director at dinny.aletheiani@yale.edu.

provenance.quote: Students seeking to earn the certificate are required to take four courses beyond the L4 level.
At least two of the four courses must be Yale advanced language courses, such as INDN 1500, INDN 1600, INDN 1700, or INDN 1800.
All courses must be taken for a letter grade, and students must achieve a grade of B or above.

With the approval of the certificate adviser, up to one course, conducted in the target language, at the appropriate advanced level, such as an independent study course (INDN 4700 or INDN 4710), graded Pass/Fail or a graduate seminar (INDN 5700) may count.
The certificate adviser may also approve the substitution of up to two credits earned during study abroad and taught in the target language to count toward the certificate requirements.
No courses taken Credit/D/Fail may be counted toward the requirements of the certificate.
Students must declare their intention to earn a Certificate ... by the 15th of January or September in their last semester at Yale.

other_policies.declaration_of_candidacy: Students must declare their intention to earn the certificate on Yale Hub as early as possible, but no later than January 15 or September 15 of their last semester.
other_policies.degree_audit: Once declared, Degree Audit tracks students’ progress toward completion of the certificate.

policies.credit_d_fail_note: Courses taken Credit/D/Fail may not be counted toward the major.

senior_requirement.description: Complete either a two-term senior essay sequence or a single-term senior essay in an approved upper-level WGSS seminar. The two-term option consists of WGSS 4490 and WGSS 4491 producing a 60–90 page essay under faculty supervision. Single-term Senior Essay.description: Senior essay of at least 30 pages written within an approved upper-level WGSS seminar (fall or spring) with instructor approval, in lieu of the course’s normal writing requirements; take one additional WGSS course to fulfill the 12-course requirement.

other_policies.surveys_timeline: Surveys should be completed by the end of the second year.
other_policies.methods_timeline: Students should consider completing at least two methods courses by the end of their junior year.
other_policies.advising: Intent to major by the end of the second year is encouraged; applications accepted on a rolling basis. Schedules for majors must be approved by the DUS.
other_policies.architecture_course_access: School of Architecture courses are open with permission of the instructor and the graduate registrar; they are not available Credit/D/Fail.
other_policies.urban_labs_credit_value: Urban Lab courses carry 1.5 credits; students who take two Urban Labs may take 4–5 electives depending on the selected senior requirement.
other_policies.additional_elective_requirement: Students choosing the one-term advanced seminar senior option must also take an additional elective.

provenance.quote: Thirteen course credits are required for the major, including the senior requirement.
3 surveys, of which one URBN course is required; surveys should be completed by the end of the second year.

Electives: 5 if yearlong senior requirement; 6 if one-term senior requirement; students who take two Urban Labs (1.5 credits each) may take 4–5 electives depending on the selected senior requirement.

other_policies.double_counting_major: No course may be applied to satisfy the requirements of both a major and the certificate.
other_policies.double_counting_areas: No single course may count for two areas of study within the certificate.
other_policies.minimum_grade: Students are required to earn at least a B– for each course.
other_policies.declaration: Students must declare intent to earn the certificate by the last day of add/drop period in their final term.
other_policies.requirement_versioning: Students are held to the requirements in effect when they declared; with DUS approval, updated requirements may be fulfilled.

provenance.quote: Prerequisite—1 term course from S&DS 1000, 1080, 1090, or 1230 (or an introductory data analysis course in another department).
Number of courses—5 term courses.
Probability and Statistical Theory—One from S&DS 2380, S&DS 2400, S&DS 2410, S&DS 2420. Advanced students may substitute S&DS 3510 or S&DS 3640 or ECE 4310.
Statistical Methodology and Data Analysis—Two from S&DS 2200 or S&DS 2300 (but not both), S&DS 2420, S&DS 3120, S&DS 3610, S&DS 3630, PLSC 2501. ECON 2136 may be substituted for S&DS 2420.
Computation & Machine Learning—One from S&DS 2620, S&DS 2650, S&DS 3170, S&DS 3650, CPSC 2230, CPSC 3810, CPSC 4770, PHYS 3780, PLSC 5060; CPSC 3230 may be substituted for CPSC 2230.
